characters: NO CHANGES ON THIS PAGE, PROVIDED TO SUPPLY ENTIRE SCENE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our camera is MOUNTED to a CAR WINDOW. Driving through a small town at night. Passing white picket fences. Kids' discarded big wheels. American flags flutter. July 4th, 1969 - Summer of Love. Vallejo, California FIREWORKS streak into the sky. Cookouts winding down. The car slows. Stops in front of a house on Beechwood Avenue. The driver HONKS. MIKE MAGEAU races out. Skinny at 19. Runs up to the window. To the camera:

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Where have you been? I've been waiting since seven. At the wheel is DARLENE FERRIN, 22, clad in a WHITE AND B JUMPSUIT. Fake eyelashes and braces make her look like 17

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE
dialogues.text: (good natured) Get in, I'm starving. I haven't eaten in like twenty four hours.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Let me drive, then.

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE
dialogues.text: No way, Jose. I have to pick up fireworks for the party tonight. Food first though. Mike doesn't move - he wants to drive.

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You coming or not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BOOM DOWN to see a local Vallejo teen hangout. Although t 60's are almost over, Vallejo didn't get the memo. Darlen (still driving) and Mike, cruising through the crowded lo She sees something offscreen. Frowning, unnerved:

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE
dialogues.text: Screw this place.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: I thought you needed to eat. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE
dialogues.text: We have time before the party. We could just go talk. Mike blinks at this. An opportunity...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Minutes later. The Corvair pulls into the lot of the loca golf course. Make out point. The car on the road behind them, passing, continuing on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darlene, parking, checking the rearview to watch the car pass. Tense, but relaxing as it goes. Mike, noticing.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Are you okay?

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE
dialogues.text: (relaxing) Fine.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: You seem a little funny. She touches his chest, playfully.

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE
dialogues.text: It's July and how many shirts are you wearing?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: (embarrassed) I'm cold.

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE
dialogues.text: You're cold in July? BANG-BANG-BANG! Mike and Darlene JUMP and Mike gives out scream! Looking around to see KIDS. A group of them in three cars. Laughing, they toss another lit string of fireworks towards the Corvair. BANG-BANG-BANG!

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Fuck off and die! The kids PEEL OUT. Leaving Mike and Darlene alone. After moment, Darlene begins giggling. RELAXING.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE
dialogues.text: (mimicking) "Fuck off and die!" She keeps laughing.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Shut up... But he's smiling. Soon he succumbs to the laughter as wel He shifts closer. Then, through the windshield - HEADLIGH Signaling to turn into the lot. The car pulls to a halt eight feet behind them on their left side. Turning out th lights. But not the engine. Mike stares at the car. Only one person in it. Odd for a make out spot.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Is that the car that was behind us before? Darlene doesn't respond.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (squinting) It is, I think he's been with us since my house- Shit, is that your husband?

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE
dialogues.text: No. But she can't take her eyes off the car. The driver makes move to get out...

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: I can to tell him to leave- She puts her hand over his. Looks at him. Don't move. The wait for what seems an eternity. Then... The other car PULLS FORWARD. Headlights click BACK ON. Passing the Corvair. They watch it go, finally disappeari over the horizon.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Who was that, Darlene?

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE
dialogues.text: Don't worry about it. Mike studies her face. Unnerved.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: So... do you want to- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DARLENE
dialogues.text: Oh, shit... Through the windshield - HEADLIGHTS, COMING BACK over the horizon. Darlene and Mike watch them reach the entrance t the parking lot. THEY TURN IN.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Let's go. Darlene, FROZEN.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Now, Darlene. The car pulls to a halt behind the Corvair. In an off-lin position, like a COP. Mike, reaching over to start the engine when - A SPOTLIGH from inside the other car hits the Corvair. The door opens and THE COP inside gets out. Walks up to t car. Flashlight outstretched, shining it in Mike and Darlene's faces, blinding them. He reaches Mike's door.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Get your I.D. (rolls down his window) Man, you kinda creeped us-— THUNK! Mike's BLOOD AND TEETH EXPLODE onto the dashboard. The muzzle of a SILENCER FLASHES. The Man KEEPS SHOOTING. BULLETS PUNCH through flesh and bone. Some shots rip stra through Mike and into Darlene. Mike is shot in the face, the neck, and the arm. Darlene shot twice in each arm, and three times in the back. The Man lowers the gun. Silence. The Man turns away. Walking back to his car. A GROAN. The Man turns. Walks back to the Corvair, reloading. Mike. Still alive. The Man FIRES TWO MORE SHOTS into Mike, propelling him in the BACK SEAT. Then TWO MORE into Darlene for good measur The Man turns and walks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: P.O.V. the front of a police motorcycle as it's HEADLIGHT cuts into the lot... OVER THIS WE HEAR a coin clink into phone. One number dialed.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE OPERATOR
dialogues.text: Vallejo Police Department? The headlight, SWINGING over asphalt until it comes to re on MIKE, slumped against the REAR of the Corvair. Blood, running down his shirt...

dialogues.speaker: A MAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I want to a report a double murder... The Officer (HOFFMAN) dismounts and runs to him...

dialogues.speaker: A MAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: If you go one mile east on Columbus Parkway to the public park, you will find kids ina brown car... Mike gestures - and Hoffman goes to the front seat to fin Darlene. In even worse shape. She tries to mouth somethin

dialogues.speaker: A MAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: They were shot with a nine millimeter Luger. I also killed those kids last year. Goodbye. CLICK. The line goes dead. SMASH TO OUR TITLE SCREEN...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: August 1, 1969. SOARING OVER WATER towards the Bay City. Magnificent spires and bridges. Bustling to life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ROBERT GRAYSMITH stands, brushing his teeth. Mid 20's. Ne to him, his 4 year old son DAVID brushes his teeth as wel Mimicking his father's movements. Graysmith does his top teeth, David does his. Graysmith smiles. David smiles. Graysmith scrubs his tongue, David scrubs his.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: And spit. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Graysmith spits. David does not.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I swallowed it.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: It was minty. Graysmith laughs and scoops David up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The tiny apartment is cluttered. Dick Tracy and old myste movie posters abound. The TV PLAYS while Graysmith ties David's shoes.

dialogues.speaker: NEWSCASTER
dialogues.text: +..at the Hall of Justice vow that the rapist will be arrested and brought to trial... Graysmith frowns and shuts off the TV.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: __, (giggling) Rapist! Rapist!

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Do daddy a favor and don't yell that at preschool, okay?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Rapist!

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Much better. He finishes David's shoes.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Are we gonna see Mom and Aaron tonight? Graysmith winces a little. Glances at the clock.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: We're gonna be late.  FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 7.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Graysmith kisses his son on the forehead and sends him inside. Then turns and RUNS...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Traffic's bad. Graysmith sketching something in his lap a he inches along. We get a good look - FOUR CARTOON SKETCH Very rough, but good...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Graysmith hustles down the sidewalk amongst pedestrians. Behind him, a MAIL TRUCK passes him on the street Both, coming up to the SAN FRANCISCO CHRONICLE, a grand old building on Fifth and Mission. The logo above the entranc Graysmith pushes through the doors into

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Graysmith hurries across the lobby towards and OPEN ELEVA The DOORS CLOSE just before he can reach it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The TRUCK halts by a LOADING DOCK. TWO MEN get out and be unloading large DUFFEL BAGS of mail onto a FLATBED DOLLY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DING! Graysmith emerges from the elevator into the controlled chaos of the paper's editorial offices. Phones ring. Typewriters clack. Reporters hustle. Graysmith head to a small COFFEE STAND manned by an ill tempered white haired midget named SHORTY.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: How's the coffee today, Shorty? Shorty points upward at his sign - "DELICIOUS AS HELL COF AND SANDWICHES".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Mailmen ride up towards the third floor with a smalle MAIL CART that's marked "Editorial".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 15 16 17 FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 8.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Graysmith gets his coffee from Shorty and heads to his de getting hung up by a CROWD OF PEOPLE standing around -— PAUL AVERY'S DESK. Avery, 30's, well dressed, crime reporter. Currently entertaining the crowd with a joke.

dialogues.speaker: AVERY
dialogues.text: ...and the bartender says, “Superman, you are one mean son of a bitch when you're drunk!" The others laugh. Graysmith pushes through them. Reaching his own desk. Devoid of people, away from the action. He opens his briefcase, just settling in when

dialogues.speaker: HYMAN
dialogues.text: Editorial in two! Graysmith begins regathering up his things as - The ELEVATOR doors across the room open and the MAILMEN emerge. We pick them up again, traveling the length of th Third Floor offices and into

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where the cart is DUMPED OUT onto a CAROL FISHER'S desk. stay on the LETTER PILE as the she begins to sort them. We zoom in on follow ONE LETTER in particular. Rush to Editor is chickenscrawled twice on it. Through the door, see GRAYSMITH - last through into the EDITORIAL ROOM.

dialogues.speaker: PECK, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: All right let's get going. Graysmith shuts the door. Carol begins opening the letter

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TEMPLETON PECK, privileged and ascoted runs the Editorial Meeting around a long oak table. As he goes through Graysmith's sketches one by one:

dialogues.speaker: PECK
dialogues.text: Horrid, horrid, not horrid, and horrid. I'm thinking we go with not horrid, don't you? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: 17B
dialogues.text: 18 FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 9.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Graysmith just nods meekly and takes the sketches back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carol slices open the Rush To Editor letter...

dialogues.speaker: PECK
dialogues.text: Paul, what's on the crime beat?

dialogues.speaker: AVERY
dialogues.text: Janice in Datebook won't let me take her to dinner. (off Peck's look) What? It's a crime. Graysmith cracks the slightest of smiles. Interrupted as door opens revealing Carol Fisher. Face grave.

dialogues.speaker: PECK
dialogues.text: Carol, what do you-

dialogues.speaker: CAROL FISHER
dialogues.text: You need to see this. She lays the Rush to Editor letter on the table. The othe crowd around. Scanning it. Peck looks up to Carol.

dialogues.speaker: PECK
dialogues.text: Go get the publisher.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHARLES DE YOUNG THEIRIOT - sits at the head of the table Old, patrician, reading the letter aloud.

dialogues.speaker: THEIRIOT
dialogues.text: Dear Editor. This is the murderer of the two teenagers last Christmas at Lake Herman and the girl on the 4th of July near the golf course in Vallejo. To prove I killed them, I shall state some facts which only I and the police know. Christmas - Brand name of ammo Super X. Ten shots were fired. The boy was on his back with his feet to the car. The girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He hands the letter to Peck with distaste. Motioning for to continue.

dialogues.speaker: PECK
dialogues.text: The girl was on her right side, feet to the west. July 4th - One girl was wearing patterned slacks. The boy was also shot in the knee. Brand name of ammo was Western. Here is part of a cipher. The other two parts of the cipher are being mailed to the editors of the Vallejo Times and S.F. Examiner. NEXT PAGE - Full of strange symbols. A CODE.

dialogues.speaker: PECK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I want you to print this cipher on the front page of your paper. In this cipher is my identity. If you do not print this cipher by the afternoon of Fry. The Ist of August 69, I will go on a kill rampage Fry night. I will cruise around all weekend killing lone people in the night then move on to kill again until I end up with a dozen people over the weekend". (pause) It's unsigned except for a symbol. Peck puts the letter down. The others move forward to examine it. Seeing the SYMBOL:

dialogues.speaker: AVERY
dialogues.text: Is it me, or does that look like a gunsight? Lost among them, Graysmith picks up THE CODE. WEIRD SYMBO litter the page in UNBROKEN BLOCK PARAGRAPHS...

dialogues.speaker: THEIRIOT
dialogues.text: Today is August first. He wants his code in the afternoon edition.

dialogues.speaker: HYMAN
dialogues.text: If the Examiner doesn't have the balls to run it, we scoop the Bay-

dialogues.speaker: PECK
dialogues.text: Charles, this man is talking about shooting twelve people- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT ll.

dialogues.speaker: HYMAN
dialogues.text: And not running this could make him do that-

dialogues.speaker: PECK
dialogues.text: If we run it we could be setting a very dangerous precedent-

dialogues.speaker: HYMAN
dialogues.text: Oh, come on, it's newsworthy-

dialogues.speaker: PECK
dialogues.text: We'd be giving this sick bastard a soapbox. What does that say to people?

dialogues.speaker: THEIRIOT
dialogues.text: Back up. The Vallejo stuff, is it true?

dialogues.speaker: HYMAN
dialogues.text: Paul?

dialogues.speaker: AVERY
dialogues.text: What, I cover crime in Vallejo? (off Theiriot's look) I cover crime in Vallejo. He rises and exits to make calls. Hyman, to Theiriot:

dialogues.speaker: HYMAN
dialogues.text: Let's shoot the code and call SFPD. If it turns out to be real, at least we'll have the material. A beat. Theiriot nods.

dialogues.speaker: HYMAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Copy! A COPY BOY sticks his head in.

dialogues.speaker: HYMAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Get Grant in here, we need some photos. Graysmith? Graysmith looks up from the code, his reverie broken.

dialogues.speaker: HYMAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Don't you have a cartoon to finish? Graysmith takes the hint. Puts down the code and leaves.  FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 12.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Graysmith, wandering back to his desk. Passing Avery who sits, dialing. Graysmith, hoping to hear the conversation

dialogues.speaker: AVERY
dialogues.text: (into the phone) This is Paul Avery from the San Francisco Chronicle, I'm looking for someone to shed some light on a letter we received...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SERGEANT JACK MULANAX (40's hook-nosed), on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: MULANAX
dialogues.text: You want to run it, run it-

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY
dialogues.text: Jack, you got a guy from the Chronicle on two!

dialogues.speaker: MULANAX
dialogues.text: Lenny, hang on... (clicks over) Sergeant Mulanax.

dialogues.speaker: AVERY
dialogues.text: Sergeant, this is Paul Avery at the Chronicle. I just wanted to check if you had an unsolved firearm related homicide on Christmas and maybe one on July 4th?

dialogues.speaker: MULANAX
dialogues.text: (through phone) Shit, you got one too?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Avery re-enters to find Hyman on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: PECK
dialogues.text: Al's on with the Examiner, they got the same letter, but with a different code. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 22 23 FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 13.

dialogues.speaker: AVERY
dialogues.text: (checking his notes) So did the Times Herald. VPD confirmed the shootings; Christmas, two teenagers on lover's lane, both DOA, David Farraday and Betty Jensen - July 4th, Darlene Ferrin and Michael (trying to pronounce) Mah- Mag- I think it's "Mayhew" He lived. She didn't.

dialogues.speaker: THEIRIOT
dialogues.text: The murder weapons?

dialogues.speaker: AVERY
dialogues.text: Match the calibers he gives in the letter. I bet the Times Herald will go with it. Hyman cups his hand over the receiver to update them:

dialogues.speaker: HYMAN
dialogues.text: Examiner says they're going but won't go front page. I say we go front page and if he kills twelve people, it's not our fault. Theiriot heaves a long sigh as the debate continues...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Graysmith, at his desk. Unfinished cartoon pushed aside. doodles something else - THE CODE. Recreated from memory. He looks up to see the ENTIRE EDITORIAL STAFF of the pape now in with Theiriot. Carol Fisher stops by his desk.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL FISHER
dialogues.text: Robert, we need- You're not done yet?

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Sorry. He switches to the cartoon.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Theiriot's still here.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL FISHER
dialogues.text: He's never here this late... Graysmith scoops up his finished cartoon and heads for  24 25 26 FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 14.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hyman speaks as Graysmith slips in.

dialogues.speaker: HYMAN
dialogues.text: ...ten minutes to press, Charles. Theiriot, quiet. Thinking. Graysmith hovers with his cartoon near Peck who whispers:

dialogues.speaker: PECK
dialogues.text: Leave it.

dialogues.speaker: THEIRIOT
dialogues.text: (deciding) Okay, replate, we'll go page 4. Weary, but happy a decision has been made, the staff head for the exit. Avery, commenting to the others:

dialogues.speaker: AVERY
dialogues.text: Twenty bucks to the first person who cracks the guy's name.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: (quietly) He won't give his name. Avery turns, surprised the quiet cartoonist has spoken. Graysmith looks a little surprised too.

dialogues.speaker: AVERY
dialogues.text: (to everybody) Anyone wanna grab a drink?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Graysmith heads home. Passing "MORTI'S", a BAR near the CHRONICLE. Looking through the window - Avery and several others from the paper laughing, carousing. He watches for moment, then moves on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE CODE - Sitting on a white table, CAMERA mounted above CHOOM! CHOOM! Flashbulbs go off. Being shot for print.  27 28 29 30 FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 15.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Graysmith dumps a stack of LIBRARY BOOKS on his desk. Dav grabs the top one happily - Yertle the Turtle. All the others, about CODEBREAKING or MURDER. Graysmith looks at the wall - covered with reproductions of JAMES BOND NOVEL COVERS. He sighs. Begins taking some down. We can't see his hands. He moves away and we see he's tacked THE CIPHE up in their place. As we push in on SYMBOLS...

dialogues.speaker: NAVY PROJECT LEADER
dialogues.text: All right, people, listen up...

dialogues.speaker: SUPERIMPOSE
dialogues.text: A group of CRYPTOGRAPHERS seated around a table with the cipher. The PROJECT LEADER addresses them.

dialogues.speaker: NAVY PROJECT LEADER
dialogues.text: The cipher is broken into three sections - each one is eight lines with seventeen symbols...

dialogues.speaker: SUPERIMPOSE
dialogues.text: A similar gathering of codebreakers.

dialogues.speaker: D.O.D. PROJECT LEADER
dialogues.text: No breaks between the symbols denoting different words, no numbers or clues to substitution keys...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two codebreakers sit at their desks, splitting a sandwich

dialogues.speaker: F.B.I. CODEBREAKER
dialogues.text: And you got symbols from at least seven different sources - Greek, Morse Code, Navy Semaphore, Weather Symbols, Astrological Signs...  31 32 FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 16.

dialogues.speaker: SUPERIMPOSE
dialogues.text: DONALD and BETTYE HARDEN sit perusing their morning paper Donald examines the PRINTED CODE. He studies it. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: DONALD
dialogues.text: Hey, take a gander at this code thingy. He passes it to his wife. She looks intrigued.

dialogues.speaker: DONALD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Want to give it a go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: August 7, 1969. Graysmith, working on the day's cartoon.

dialogues.speaker: AVERY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: The guy who used to sit there was a great cartoonist. Graysmith looks up to see Avery.

dialogues.speaker: AVERY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Bob Bastion. Now he's on public television for some reason... Paul Avery.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Robert Graysmith. I've been here nine months.

dialogues.speaker: AVERY
dialogues.text: You were right, by the way. He didn't give his name. That gets Graysmith's attention.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Who cracked it?

dialogues.speaker: AVERY
dialogues.text: A history teacher and his wife in Salinas. He lays the translation of the code down on the desk. Graysmith picks it up. Begins reading aloud, the horror growing on his face with every sentence. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 32 FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 17.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: I like killing people because it is so much fun. It is more fun than killing wild game in the forest because man is the most dangerous animal of all to kill. Something gives me the most thrilling experience, it is even better than getting your rocks off with a girl. The best part of it is that when I die I will be reborn in paradise and they - They I have killed will become my slaves. I will not give you my name because you will try to slow down or stop my collecting of slaves for the afterlife. Silence. Graysmith, shaken.

dialogues.speaker: AVERY
dialogues.text: Methinks our friend is a tad bit fuckered in the head. I heard he even sent Vallejo a code key to help. Impatient prick, isn't he?

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: What are those letters at the bottom? He points and we see them - EBEORIETMETHHPITI

dialogues.speaker: AVERY
dialogues.text: Leftovers? Maybe an anagram? Graysmith begins writing, trying different permutations o the letters: Robert Hemphill, Van M. Blackman, Robert Emm the Hippie...

dialogues.speaker: AVERY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You're pretty good at those. (noticing) "Robert Emmet the Hippie"? Graysmith tries more. Avery watches. After a bit:

dialogues.speaker: AVERY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How'd you know he wasn't gonna give his name? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 32 33 34 35 FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 18.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: (to himself) Man is the most dangerous animal of all... Man is the most dangerous animal of all... He continues writing and mumbling. This guy is strange. Avery walks away, intrigued. Passing Peck, who whispers:

dialogues.speaker: PECK
dialogues.text: Paul, editorial now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The EDITORIAL STAFF huddled, going through something. Ave pushes through them. Bumping into Hyman.

dialogues.speaker: HYMAN
dialogues.text: Another letter, more of the same -— details about the murders. He taped a flashlight to the gun, that's how he hit them in the dark-

dialogues.speaker: THEIRIOT
dialogues.text: But he gave himself a name. Avery looks down as we push in on the NEW LETTER:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VROOM! A VOLKSWAGEN KARMANN GHIA ROARS past camera, speed down a winding road carved out of the forest above LAKE BERRYESSA. Two college kids, BRYAN HARTNELL at the wheel, CECELIA SHEPHARD next to him. Young. Pretty. Smitten. September 27, 1969 - Napa County, California

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sun, creeping down. The light's gone golden. Bryan an Cecelia lie side by side, on a peninsula. Two trees shade them. No one else in sight. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 35 FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 19.

dialogues.speaker: BRYAN
dialogues.text: This used to be a town. The county decided the land would work better as a lake, so they flooded it. There's an entire-

dialogues.speaker: CECELIA
dialogues.text: -hidden city under the water. We were here last spring, remember? He smiles. She smiles back but then SEES SOMETHING.

dialogues.speaker: CECELIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Somebody else is here. Bryan stays in his position. Not looking.

dialogues.speaker: BRYAN
dialogues.text: It's a public park.

dialogues.speaker: CECELIA
dialogues.text: He's watching us.

dialogues.speaker: BRYAN
dialogues.text: Well, we're very good looking. Cecelia playfully swats him. Looking back to the brush.

dialogues.speaker: CECELIA
dialogues.text: Where'd he go? She scans the landscape.

dialogues.speaker: CECELIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: There. He went behind a tree.

dialogues.speaker: BRYAN
dialogues.text: (still not looking) So? He's taking a leak. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: CECELIA
dialogues.text: Oh, my God, he's got a gun! Bryan turning to see - The TREE only TWENTY FEET AWAY. A MAN IN BLACK has emerged from behind it. Wearing A HOOD l an EXECUTIONER'S MASK. Slits for eyeholes and over them, sunglasses. The hood's front with a CROSS STITCHED into i which QUARTERS A CIRCLE. A SHEATHED KNIFE hangs from his left side and a GUN IN HAND. Bryan and Cecelia, beginning stand... The Man walks over, aiming the weapon at them. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: THE MAN
dialogues.text: Don't move, I want your money and your car keys. Don't move.

dialogues.speaker: BRYAN
dialogues.text: Whatever you say. We'll cooperate, okay? What do you want us to do? The Man motions for them to stand. They do. Bryan is "water side" standing parallel to the man. Cecelia is to Bryan's right. The Man keeps his distance. Bryan pulls ou the his wallet and tosses it. Searching his pockets for t keys, motor-mouthing:

dialogues.speaker: BRYAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You're welcome to everything I have, but is there something more I could do? Could I give you a check or something?

dialogues.speaker: THE MAN
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: BRYAN
dialogues.text: I could give you my phone number, and, you know- maybe I could give you more help than you think you need-

dialogues.speaker: CECELIA
dialogues.text: (explaining) He's a sociology major.

dialogues.speaker: THE MAN
dialogues.text: Sorry, I can't remember where I put the keys, they might be on the blanket, can I- The Man motions with the gun - Bryan leans down to search their blanket.

dialogues.speaker: BRYAN
dialogues.text: Can I ask you a question? I read in Reader's Digest that thieves don't always have their guns loaded-

dialogues.speaker: THE MAN
dialogues.text: It's loaded.

dialogues.speaker: CECELIA
dialogues.text: Bryan, do what he says. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 35 FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 21.

dialogues.speaker: BRYAN
dialogues.text: I am, I am. (finding them) Here's the keys. Bryan tosses them.

dialogues.speaker: THE MAN
dialogues.text: I want her to tie you up.

dialogues.speaker: BRYAN
dialogues.text: Okay. He pulls some lengths of hollow core clothesline from beh his back. Hands them to Cecelia who immediately goes behi Bryan and begins tying his hands behind his back, loosely Bryan, to Cecelia as she works:

dialogues.speaker: BRYAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (whispering) I might be able to get the gun-

dialogues.speaker: CECELIA
dialogues.text: Bryan! The Man points the gun at his head.

dialogues.speaker: THE MAN
dialogues.text: Don't get any ideas-

dialogues.speaker: BRYAN
dialogues.text: I won't-

dialogues.speaker: THE MAN
dialogues.text: I killed a guard escaping from prison in Montana.

dialogues.speaker: BRYAN
dialogues.text: I'm not doing anything, okay?

dialogues.speaker: THE MAN
dialogues.text: I'm not afraid to kill again.

dialogues.speaker: BRYAN
dialogues.text: (after a bit; as she ties) What was the name of that prison? The Man doesn't respond. They stand in silence as Cecelia finishes. The Man immediately goes to her and begins bind her hands behind her back (he may have holstered the gun do this). (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BRYAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You said it was in Montana, right?

dialogues.speaker: THE MAN
dialogues.text: I'm taking your car and going to Mexico. The Man finishes with Cecelia and steps behind Bryan.

dialogues.speaker: THE MAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: She tied you loose, didn't she? He CRANKS the ropes around Bryan's wrists tighter.

dialogues.speaker: THE MAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Get on your stomach so I can tie your feet.

dialogues.speaker: BRYAN
dialogues.text: Come on, man. I didn't complain when you tied our hands-

dialogues.speaker: THE MAN
dialogues.text: On your stomach-

dialogues.speaker: BRYAN
dialogues.text: It gets cold at night, we could freeze- The Man steps points the gun at him at point blank range:

dialogues.speaker: THE MAN
dialogues.text: Get down! Right now! Bryan and Cecelia do. The Man binds Bryan's feet to his hands in silence. Does the same to Cecelia. Hog-tying the Then steps back, surveying his handiwork.

dialogues.speaker: BRYAN
dialogues.text: Now that it's all said and done - was the gun really loaded? The Man pops the clip. Removes a SHINY BULLET. Showing Bryan. Then puts it away. Moving behind him, out of his line of vision. Bryan, lying there, trying to figure out he's going to get himself untied once the Man leaves when The Man pulls the KNIFE from the scabbard and STABS BRYAN THE BACK. It happens so quick, it takes a moment for Cece to realize what's happening. And then she begins to SCREA The Man pulls the knife out of Bryan. RAISES IT AGAIN... And Dear God, we're actually going to have to watch this. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 35 36 FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 23.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Blood flowing. On Cecelia. Screaming. Crimson flecks on her face. Bryan's face, in a daze. Jarred forcibly every time the Man stabs down. He does it six times, then lurch off him. He turns and STABS CECELIA. She tries to roll. H just keeps stabbing. Her side. Her front. Bryan's eyes. Finding Cecelia. Seeing what's happening to her. And then looking away...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Later. The screaming is done. The sun, almost down. Cecelia has rolled to her side. Her bound wrists now up b Bryan's mouth and he's trying to CHEW THEM FREE. He spits out some rope. Pulling at the knot with his teeth between sobs... Her hand comes free. She moves... and SCREAMS. We can't hear it, because OVER THIS WE HEAR - More coins in pay phone. Dialing. Ringing...

dialogues.speaker: NAPA POLICEMAN
dialogues.text: Napa Police Department? Bryan rolls. Positioning his wrists by Cecelia's free han

dialogues.speaker: THE MAN
dialogues.text: I want to report a murder - no, a double murder. With an incredible effort she begins tugging on his ropes

dialogues.speaker: THE MAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: They are two miles north of Park Headquarters. They were in a white Volkswagen Kharmann Ghia. Bryan's wrists come free...

dialogues.speaker: THE MAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'm the one that did it. CLICK. He's hung up. Bryan, pulling the ropes from his legs. He crawls to Cecelia. Kisses her once on the lips.

dialogues.speaker: BRYAN
dialogues.text: I'll get someone... Somehow, he manages to STAND. Stooped over, arms crossed around his stomach. Just one step is an amazing effort. Bryan takes three before COLLAPSING. He only made it six feet. He rises again. Walks again. Falls again. Finally he gives up... And begins to crawl.  37 38 39 FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 24.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ..-above the Lake. Bryan's car, still pulled off to the s of the empty road. A PARK RANGER slows at the abandoned c Nothing out of the ordinary. He rolls his eyes. Kids. He drives on. We stay on the car. Slowly moving to the passenger side to reveal SCRAWLED IN MARKER ON THE DOOR: °

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON - Graysmith's fingers grip a pencil. SKETCHING.

dialogues.speaker: AVERY, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: The boy lived, the girl didn't. Imagine surviving something like that. And the dates on the car - the two Vallejo killings and now the one in Napa. Why Napa? Pulling back to reveal it's a sketch of ZODIAC IN COSTUME

dialogues.speaker: AVERY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What's he doing out of Vallejo? And- Sweet Christmas, what are you drawing? By now we can tell we're by Graysmith's desk.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: The kid who survived, this is what he said Zodiac was wearing- He stops, his EYES GOING WIDE as something clicks.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh, my God... He leaps up and races off. Practically knocking over Hyma An odd duck, that one. Hyman sits and picks up the sketch

dialogues.speaker: HYMAN
dialogues.text: Jesus, where'd he come up with that? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: AVERY
dialogues.text: It's Zodiac at the lake. (re: Graysmith) What's his story, anyway? He seems a little farther out than far out.

dialogues.speaker: HYMAN
dialogues.text: Graysmith? He's a fucking boy scout. Doesn't smoke, doesn't drink, doesn't curse.

dialogues.speaker: AVERY
dialogues.text: Horrible. (seeing) Aaand he's back. As Graysmith returns to the desk clutching a FILM BOOK. H puts it down, frantically paging through it. He turns the book to Avery and Hyman and stabs the page: A black and white FILM STILL from an old movie - a man DRESSED IDENTICALLY AS THE ZODIAC.

dialogues.speaker: HYMAN
dialogues.text: What is that?

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: A still from The Most Dangerous Game.

dialogues.speaker: AVERY
dialogues.text: "The Most Dangerous Game"?

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: It's a movie about a count who hunts people for sport. "Man is the most dangerous animal of all" I knew I'd heard it somewhere!

dialogues.speaker: AVERY
dialogues.text: And this is the Count?

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Exactly. "Count Zaroff".

dialogues.speaker: AVERY
dialogues.text: "Zaroff" with a 2?

dialogues.speaker: HYMAN
dialogues.text: Jesus. He's hunting people...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: October 11, 1969. We SOAR OVER the CITY, passing through half completed TRANSAMERICA PYRAMID. A RADIO SHOW: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: RADIO HOST, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ...news on the Twenty. Because of the recent attacks police have ordered curfews in effect tonight for the following counties - Napa, Solano, Contra Costa, Alameda, Marin, and San Mateo so please everyone, stay safe, stay inside, and keep calling. Pushing down into the bustling streets of the city - peop way too busy with their urban lives to be bothered with anything else.

dialogues.speaker: RADIO HOST, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Vic in San Francisco, you're on the line. So the Zodiac doesn't scare you?

dialogues.speaker: CALLER 1, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Heck no, the guy's just doing his thing out in the sticks. What's really scary is the yippies down in the Haight with their "free love". 4l EXT. MASON AND GEARY -- NIGHT 4l Heavy foot traffic. The THEATER CROWD just being let out. couple hippies play guitar for change.

dialogues.speaker: RADIO HOST, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Alfred from Vacaville feels differently - Alfred, are you gonna take that?

dialogues.speaker: CALLER 2, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Well, I agree about the hippies, but I resent him calling us "the sticks" - those were nice clean cut young people that man killed. We have good solid Christian communities here in the North Bay.  42 43 FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 27.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We track the Cab's progress, moving from the business and theater district towards the residential PACIFIC HEIGHTS.

dialogues.speaker: RADIO HOST, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: You bring up a good question - is the Zodiac a Satanist? Amber from Oakland, what do you think?

dialogues.speaker: CALLER 3, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Well, the symbols look Satanic, but that's not what I called about - my question is where does the Chronicle get off encouraging him like that?

dialogues.speaker: RADIO HOST, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: A great question, and I'd also ask - since when did a big city paper like the Chronicle even care about what happens in rural communities like Vallejo? Aren't they covering this just to sell more papers? Alison in San Francisco?

dialogues.speaker: CALLER 4, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I don't know about them caring or not caring but I do know The Zodiac demanded they print his letters or he'd kill more people-

dialogues.speaker: CALLER 3, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (breaking in) But they didn't have to. And he's killed more people anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cab slowing. A posh part of the city. The sidewalks, empty. Pulling to halt at the corner of Washington and Cherry. The Cabbie puts it in park...

dialogues.speaker: RADIO HOST
dialogues.text: A great point Amber. So a general question for all our callers, what do you think he'll do next? BOOM! The Cabbie's HEAD SNAPS FORWARD. Shot by his PASSENGER, who we don't see. Silence. As we begin to pull away from the CAB... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 43 FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 27A.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The PASSENGER gets out. Moving around the car. Gets into the FRONT PASSENGER seat. Leaves the door ajar. He seems be (but is not) cradling the Cabbie's head in his lap. We still pulling up and away slowly, across the street... OVER THIS: A phone ringing. Picked up.

dialogues.speaker: SFPD OPERATOR, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: San Francisco Police-

dialogues.speaker: TEENAGE GIRL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Yeah, there's a fight! In a cab! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SFPD OPERATOR, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: What is your location?

dialogues.speaker: TEENAGE GIRL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: The corner of Washington and Cherry, one's drunk! We think he's robbing him! The Man gets out again. Walks around the front to the Driver's side door. Holding a RAG. Still PULLING BACK...

dialogues.speaker: SFPD OPERATOR, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Is the crime still in progress?

dialogues.speaker: TEENAGE GIRL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Yes! And then, the sound of a MACHINE GUN...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...it's a TOMMY-GUN. Coming from an old tape recorder. Graysmith lays on the bed next to his son in the dark, listening to a DICK TRACY radio program on cassette:

dialogues.speaker: FLAT-TOP, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Take that Tracy! Come on boys, let's go! The sound of squealing tires. Then pistol shots.

dialogues.speaker: FLAT-TOP, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: He shot our tires! Darn that Tracy! The sound of a car crashing. David giggles. Graysmith, who's heard this a thousand times, mouths the next lines:

dialogues.speaker: DICK TRACY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You boys are under arrest!

dialogues.speaker: ANNOUNCER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (as the music swells) Join us for the next incredible episode of Dick Tracy! Graysmith stops the tape. He rises, tucking David in.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Enough for tonight.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Dad, what's Zodiac? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Graysmith pauses. Carefully:

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: He's a very bad man. A criminal.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Who is he?

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Nobody knows.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Are you gonna catch him? Graysmith smiles.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: You should get some sleep. He kisses David on the forehead and moves to the door.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Somebody's gonna catch him, right? In the doorway, Graysmith turns back.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Who always catches the bad guys?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: The good guys?

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: That's right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A couple, asleep. The PHONE RINGS. The man reaches for it Misses. Knocks over the bedside lamp. CRASH!

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: Ah, nuts... His WIFE switches on her lamp. The man sits up and we get our first real look at INSPECTOR DAVE TOSCHI. Handsome, Italian-American. Groggy, he answers the phone.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Whoever this is, you owe me a lamp. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 45 46 47 FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 30.

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: (on phone) Cabbie's been shot three blocks from the Presidio.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: I didn't do it. I've been with my bride all night, she can vouch.

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: You'll pick me up?

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: Let me just describe the lamp you're gonna buy for me- CLICK. Armstrong, gone. Toschi hangs up. His wife sighs.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI'S WIFE
dialogues.text: I'll go put on the Folgers...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A lone cop stands waiting. Plain clothes. Silver hair. Kind face. This is BILL ARMSTRONG. A CAR pulls up to the corner, driven by Toschi. Armstrong gets in.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: I was sound asleep.

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: Suspect's a Negro Male Adult. Walt's on scene, he's locked off the cab and secured the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: Seriously, dead asleep. My eyes were closed and everything. Armstrong pulls a box of Animal Crackers from his pocket hands them to Toschi, who begins munching on them as he drives.

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: You ever try Japanese food?

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: You mean like teryaki? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: No, like the urchin and raw fish.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: I'm eating here, Bill.

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: I always wanted to try it.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: So. Why don't you? Armstrong stares out the window.

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: Haven't gotten around to it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHOOM! KLIEG LIGHTS on a Fire Department "Spotlight Vehic snap on, illuminating the block. An AMBULANCE and CRIME L VAN are already on scene. Uniforms work through the crowd comparing faces to a physical description they've gotten. Toschi pulls to a halt at the edge of the scene and gets with Armstrong. Homicide INSPECTOR WALTER KRACKE approach

dialogues.speaker: KRACKE
dialogues.text: Evening, gents. Lovely night for a botched robbery, huh?

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: Third one this week. The end of summer rush.

dialogues.speaker: KRACKE
dialogues.text: I got foot patrols going through the park and the dogs are on their way. Victim's name is Paul Stine. (gestures to the Ambulance driver) Dousette pronounced him at 10:10. Suspect fired one shot, back of the head, driver's wallet and car keys are missing.

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: How do you know his name? Kracke points to a distraught AFRICAN AMERICAN MAN. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: KRACKE
dialogues.text: Leroy there came down from Yellow Cab to I.D him. Neighborhood's pretty high end for this kind of thing, so I already set up transpo for the cab and the coroner's rolling. Toschi, noticing the crowd of onlookers and other cops lingering near the body and the car.

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: Any witnesses?

dialogues.speaker: KRACKE
dialogues.text: Kids who called it in saw the suspect from that window. He points to a THREE STORY HOUSE across the street.

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: They hear a shot?

dialogues.speaker: KRACKE
dialogues.text: No, they first saw him in the front seat, thought he was a drunk fighting with the driver. Oldest kid ran downstairs to get a better look from that window, described him as a white male, glasses, crewcut, stocky and wearing a dark jacket.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: I thought he was black.

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: That's the description that went out to radio cars.

dialogues.speaker: KRACKE
dialogues.text: We already corrected it. You guys need anything else?

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: Nah, get outta here.

dialogues.speaker: KRACKE
dialogues.text: Thanks. (to Armstrong; grinning) Happy Birthday. Toschi turns to his partner. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: No kidding, it's your birthday?

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: That's great. Happy Birthday.

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: Thanks. You want the body or the scene?

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: Body. The partners split up. A well practiced ritual. Toschi go to the cab where LAB TECHS are photographing the DRIVER, lies in the bloody front seat. One tech, DAGITZ looks up Toschi approaches.

dialogues.speaker: DAGITZ
dialogues.text: Dave. Looks like he wiped the cab down pretty good but we've got some blood over here. He points to the door jamb. Toschi pulls out a flashlight examine it. Squinting:

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: Print?

dialogues.speaker: DAGITZ
dialogues.text: Could very well be. We'll dust it at the Hall. Odd thing is, we also got gloves.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: The suspect's?

dialogues.speaker: DAGITZ
dialogues.text: There's blood on them. Toschi flips open his notebook and begins to SKETCH the scene. He works quickly, using a TAPE MEASURE to gauge distances. When he's done:

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: Got enough? The PHOTOGRAPHER nods. To Dagitz:

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Help me roll him. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He and Dagitz take hold of the body and hoist it out of t cab and onto the pavement. The crowd MURMURS at the sight Toschi leans in to check the cab's floor. Discovering:

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Got a casing. Single. Nine mil. The Photographer leans in. Flashbulbs pop. Documenting th position of the shiny copper casing. Toschi measures its position. Adds it to the sketch.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Tweezers? Dagitz hands him tweezers. Toschi gingerly bags the casin Straightens up, as Armstrong approaches.

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: Nothing from the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: Okay - I'm your shooter, an Adult Negro Male who happens to be a stocky Caucasian. I flag a cab, I give this address- Did he give this address? Who's got the fare book? A UNIFORM produces the bagged book. Armstrong checks it.

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: Says Washington and Maple. One block that way. He points. Toschi jogs down the street a little towards t other corner. Sees what he needs to and jogs back.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: Lighting's the same there so maybe I see somebody walking their dog.

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: You don't want a witness so you say "go down a block". Cabbie pulls over-

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: And I wait till he puts it in park cause I'm smart and I don't want him hitting the accelerator after I shoot him. Toschi stands behind the Uniform, using him as he acts ou the rest. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: Cabbie stops, puts it in park, boom.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: I shoot him on the right - he slumps right?

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: Maybe you've got your hand on his collar when you shoot.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: Either way, I just dumped a quart of blood into the front seat.

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: So why do you get into the front seat?

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: The money?

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: But he's dead. You could just reach over the seat, pull his wallet and never get near all the blood. Why do you get into the front seat?

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: Cause I'm an idiot?

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: You're not an idiot, you waited for him to put it in park.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: Let me see the fare book... Armstrong hands it over. Toschi peruses it.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I am an idiot, I'm his third fare of the night. I just killed a guy for eight bucks. (to Armstrong) You have any more animal crackers?

dialogues.speaker: UNIFORM
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: They're in the car. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 48 49 50 FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 36.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: I was gonna finish them later. (pause) Fine. Toschi rises and goes back towards the car...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The DOORBELL RINGS. The FATHER answers it. Toschi holding crackers.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: Are you a reporter?

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: (flashing a badge) No, sir, SFPD. I need to have a word with your children alone, one at a time-

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: They just saw a man die. I'm not letting them out of my sight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toschi sits across from the SIX KIDS, who inhale the anim crackers as they talk, breathlessly overlapping:

dialogues.speaker: YEAR OLD, (TEEN BOY)
dialogues.text: It looked like they were Yeah, and he had a rag- drunk and fighting-

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: Inside the car, he had a rag?

dialogues.speaker: YEAR OLD, (TEEN GIRL)
dialogues.text: No outside- He came around the side of the car and was wiping stuff-

dialogues.speaker: YEAR OLD, (FRIEND)
dialogues.text: (mouth full of crackers) No, he was, and then he put I didn't see him wiping stuff- it in his pocket-

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: First time you saw him he was in the front seat. Then he gets out-

dialogues.speaker: YEAR OLD, (TEEN BOY)
dialogues.text: And comes around to the driver's side with the rag- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 50 51 52 53 54 FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 37.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: Did you see his face?

dialogues.speaker: YEAR OLD, (TEEN BOY)
dialogues.text: Yeah- Sort of-

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What did he look like? The kids think about this for a second.

dialogues.speaker: YEAR OLD, (TEEN BOY)
dialogues.text: Normal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: October 14, 1969. Carol Fisher, sorting through letters. stops at the last one. A CROSSED CIRCLE in the return address corner. On the front in BLUE FELT PEN: SF CHRONICLE, SAN FRAN, CALIF..

dialogues.speaker: PLEASE RUSH TO EDITOR.
dialogues.text: She takes a letter opener and slices open the top...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Graysmith, sketching. From down the hall, CAROL'S SCREAM!

dialogues.speaker: AVERY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: This is the Zodiac speaking...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toschi and Armstrong enter the newspaper's lobby...

dialogues.speaker: AVERY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I am the murderer of the taxi driver over by Washington Street and Maple Street last night...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toschi and Armstrong stride down the corridor towards the conference room, past staring REPORTERS... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: 54A
dialogues.text: 55 FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 38.

dialogues.speaker: AVERY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: To prove this, here is a blood stained piece of his shirt...

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: A 3 by 5 PIECE of grey and white SHIRT CLOTH, SOAKED IN 5 BLOOD. Neatly torn, not cut. It sits on a table in

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Surrounded by Graysmith, Avery, Theiriot, and the Editori staff. Avery, reading the letter aloud:

dialogues.speaker: AVERY
dialogues.text: I am the same man who did in the people in the North Bay Area. The S.F. Police could have caught me last night if they had searched the park properly instead of holding road races- The doors open and Toschi and Armstrong enter.

dialogues.speaker: AVERY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Dave.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: Paul. Where's the shirt? Theiriot leads him over to the bloodstained cloth.

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: There's your rag from the kids.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: So he sits in the front seat to rip off a piece of the shirt...

dialogues.speaker: AVERY
dialogues.text: Is this on the record-

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: What do you think, Paul?

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: HYMAN GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: He takes credit for Vallejo It's worse than that. and Napa- The room turns to look at him. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PECK
dialogues.text: You get your cartoon in yet, Robert? Graysmith frowns. Heads for the door once again. When he' gone, Toschi turns back to Theiriot.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: What did he mean "worse"?

dialogues.speaker: THEIRIOT
dialogues.text: Read the last part.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: School children make nice targets. I think I shall wipe out a school bus some morning. Just shoot out the front tire and the pick off the kiddies as they come bouncing out- Jesus, who handles buses-— Department of Transportation?

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: School board. Toschi, scoops up the letter, heading for the door...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Graysmith, by Avery's empty desk. Digging in his trash fo info on Zodiac. He straightens up when he sees the Detectives exit the Conference Room. Toschi and Armstrong rapid conference as they walk:

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: We need matches on blood and fabric-

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: I'll call Napa and Vallejo, pull the other letters and get them up to Sacramento for handwriting-

dialogues.speaker: AVERY
dialogues.text: Dave, hold up! Is it true you got a print off the cab?

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: Yeah, we got a partial in blood, but that's not for publication-

dialogues.speaker: AVERY
dialogues.text: Hey, it's me. Toschi and Armstrong step on the elevator and are gone. Avery heads back to his desk. Graysmith follows. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Did he say they had a print?

dialogues.speaker: AVERY
dialogues.text: Partial.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Wow. Wow. Did you notice he was wearing his gun like Bullit?

dialogues.speaker: AVERY
dialogues.text: Steve McQueen got that from Toschi. He sits and begins typing his notes.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Does he think Zodiac's gonna send another code? I think he's gonna send another code-

dialogues.speaker: AVERY
dialogues.text: (still typing) Robert? You're looming. Graysmith slinks back to his desk. People bustle around h electricity in the air. And there's nothing for him to do

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twilight through the windows. Theiriot has gathered the entire Editorial staff. We PAN across them as he speaks..

dialogues.speaker: THEIRIOT
dialogues.text: In cooperation with SFPD, we will run the Zodiac letter without including the threat on school children. We do not want to start a citywide panic so I'm asking all of you to keep this confidential. Just go about your daily business...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Graysmith stands on a corner with David. Uncomfortable wi his father's presence.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: You don't have to wait with me.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: It's okay. I want to. A YELLOW SCHOOL BUS rounds the corner. Rumbling towards them. Graysmith exhales. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 58 59 60 FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 41.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: David hefts his backpack as the bus approaches. Graysmith watches him. Preparing to get on. The bus stops. The Driver cranks open the door. David steps forward... Graysmith can't take it. STOPS HIM.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Dad? Graysmith looks to the Driver. Apologetic.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: I'm gonna drive him myself today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sacramento, California. AN EYE behind a magnifying glass. Chief of Questioned Documents - Sherwood Morrill. He studies the Zodiac letters side by side. Meticulous, s work. Toschi stands next to him. Maddened by the pace. Morrill makes a note.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: MORRILL
dialogues.text: Similarities in the lower case ris. He keeps going. Moves onto the e's. Makes another note.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: And that?

dialogues.speaker: MORRILL
dialogues.text: That was you waiting in the hall if you speak again. I have to concentrate.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: Sorry-

dialogues.speaker: MORRILL
dialogues.text: Sorry counts as speaking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SLAM! Morrill shuts the door behind Toschi, locking him o Armstrong, on the couch across from the doorway, a couple snacks on his lap. He's eating chips. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: There are similarities in the lower case r's. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Armstrong tosses Toschi a box of Animal Crackers. He tear them open.

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: We have to release the bus threat.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: It'll screw us.

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: We're already screwed. We just went from routine cabbie shooting to "Mass Murderer Targets Kids". Silence. Toschi sighs. The door to Morrill's office opens and he steps out with a grave look on his face...

dialogues.speaker: ANCHORMAN
dialogues.text: The Zodiac Killer has come to San Francisco...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Friday, October 17, 1969. Graysmith and David, watching T

dialogues.speaker: ANCHORMAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Confirmation tonight from the San Francisco Police Department that in his latest taunting letter which takes credit for the murder of cab driver Paul Stine, the Zodiac has threatened to "wipe out a school bus and pick off the kiddies as they come bouncing- CLICK. Graysmith shuts the TV off, but not quick enough. David stares at him. Terrified.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Avery, pounding away at his typewriter on an article as t news report continues in the background: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ANCHORMAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: ..-if you think you might know who the Zodiac is, you can call the San Francisco Police Department's tipline...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Saturday, October 18, 1969. PHONES RING OFF THE HOOK. The place has become ZODIAC CENTRAL. PAN across the DETECTIVE ALL ON THE PHONE. Overlapping:

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE 1
dialogues.text: Yes, sir, we'll add your dry cleaner to our suspect list...

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE 2
dialogues.text: ...Vice President Agnew's whereabouts are pretty well established, ma'am... Ending on Toschi, hanging up his phone. Behind him CAPTAI MARTIN LEE pulls on a tie and straightens it.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN LEE
dialogues.text: Press conference is at four, I need to tell them where we are. Toschi's phone begins RINGING AGAIN. He ignores it.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: We're coordinating with the school board, and expect a break in the case very soon.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN LEE
dialogues.text: Where are we really?

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: Swamped. When they can't get through on the tip line they call the switchboard and keep getting put through.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN LEE
dialogues.text: Hard suspects?

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: About ninety an hour - we're up to around five hundred.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN LEE
dialogues.text: Can you narrow it down? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: If I could get out of this chair- (answering the phone) Homicide, could you hold please? He puts the phone back down. RINGING AGAIN, almost immediately. Captain Lee pulls on his blazer.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN LEE
dialogues.text: I have to tell them the entire force is on this.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: How many men can you give me?

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN LEE
dialogues.text: For now it's just you and Bill. And Monday's a school day.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: I got three daughters, Chief.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN LEE
dialogues.text: Where's Armstrong?

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: On with Vallejo. (answering phone) Homicide, Toschi... PAN TO - Armstrong in mid conversation.

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: We're playing catch up here. I'd like to set up a meeting with your survivor, Michael Mageau-

dialogues.speaker: MULANAX
dialogues.text: Can't. Skipped town.

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: The only guy who's seen Zodiac without a mask is missing?

dialogues.speaker: MULANAX
dialogues.text: When he was still in the hospital we could show him line ups every day. Soon as he got out he left. Don't think he wants to have anything to do with this. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: Well, if you could just send us everything you've got-

dialogues.speaker: MULANAX
dialogues.text: Road goes both ways - we need that print you lifted from the cab. Also, we should've been in on the handwriting.

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: I apologize, things have been moving fast. Who should I talk to in Napa so we can coordinate?

dialogues.speaker: MULANAX
dialogues.text: Ken Narlow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KEN NARLOW, now on the phone with Armstrong.

dialogues.speaker: NARLOW
dialogues.text: We should have been in on the handwriting.

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: I apologize, things have been moving fast. We're gonna need your scene photos-

dialogues.speaker: NARLOW
dialogues.text: Can't help you.

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: Ken, I don't want to get into a jurisdictional thing-

dialogues.speaker: NARLOW
dialogues.text: We didn't have a crime scene. Ranger who found the kids literally swept everything into a picnic blanket. All we got were the Wing Walker prints.

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: The what? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: NARLOW
dialogues.text: Bootprints to and from the scene were made by size ten and a half Wing Walkers - they're a type of boot specifically designed to walk on the wings of planes, exclusively sold at military PX's. Armstrong, writing this down...

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: You can only buy at a PX with a military I.D, so our suspect could be military. Did you narrow your list off this?

dialogues.speaker: NARLOW
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: Did Vallejo?

dialogues.speaker: NARLOW
dialogues.text: I don't know. I don't work in Vallejo, I work here.

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: Can you send us a photo of the bootprint?

dialogues.speaker: NARLOW
dialogues.text: Yes, can you send us the handwriting stuff?

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: I though Questioned Documents already did.

dialogues.speaker: NARLOW
dialogues.text: Nope. Vallejo's got it, we don't.

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, I'll have Questioned Documents- No, I'll fax it to you.

dialogues.speaker: NARLOW
dialogues.text: We don't have a fax yet.

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: Okay, I'll mail it. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: NARLOW
dialogues.text: We'll mail ours but call Mulanax, maybe Vallejo can get you a mimeo quicker.

dialogues.speaker: MULANAX
dialogues.text: Why don't you just get a photo off the original plaster cast?

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: We'd have to wait because they don't have a fax.

dialogues.speaker: MULANAX
dialogues.text: We don't have a fax.

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: Look- I just want to get us coordinated.

dialogues.speaker: MULANAX
dialogues.text: Have you called Solano Sheriff's Office?

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: Why would I call Solano?

dialogues.speaker: MULANAX
dialogues.text: Cause the two kids who got killed last Christmas were Solano's.

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: I thought they were Vallejo.

dialogues.speaker: MULANAX
dialogues.text: They were over the county line. You're gonna need to coordinate with them too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Armstrong hangs up the phone. At the end of his rope. Then he notices Toschi's face. Grim.

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: What now?  68 FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 48.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toschi and Armstrong sit in the back of the black and whi In the front seat are two patrolmen, FOUKE and ZELMS. The drive through Pacific Heights. Close to the Stine scene.

dialogues.speaker: PATROLMAN FOUKE
dialogues.text: We got the call to circle the scene, look for a negro-

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: So this is three minutes Where was he? after the shooting?

dialogues.speaker: PATROLMAN ZELMS PATROLMAN FOUKE
dialogues.text: About three, yeah- There, where that woman is.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: Were you driving this way or the other way?

dialogues.speaker: PATROLMAN ZELMS
dialogues.text: This way.

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: This is Jackson and Maple. So, the cab is catty corner one block that way-

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: Did you slow down?

dialogues.speaker: PATROLMAN FOUKE
dialogues.text: (across to Toschi) Of course we slowed down! But dispatch said he was a Negro Male Adult-

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI PATROLMAN FOUKE
dialogues.text: They corrected that. -this guy was white, not ina hurry, sort of lumbering along-

dialogues.speaker: PATROLMAN ZELMS ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: But at the time they hadn't-— Lumbering?

dialogues.speaker: PATROLMAN FOUKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (answering Armstrong) Like he was shuffling. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: He was stocky? Had a crewcut?

dialogues.speaker: PATROLMAN FOUKE
dialogues.text: Yeah, but it was dark, he was ina dark jacket, we didn't think-

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: Did you talk to him?

dialogues.speaker: PATROLMAN FOUKE
dialogues.text: (beat) No. Zelms shoots hima look. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: You need to sit down with a sketch artist, so we can get a new composite. Neither of the Patrolmen can look at him. Toschi, realizi this is a nightmare for them, too.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: Guys? It's okay. The Patrolmen's faces - no it's not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sunday, October 19, 1969. CLOSE ON - the COMPOSITE SKETCH ZODIAC as it's being handed out to a collection of BUS DRIVERS who sit in folding chairs. Smoking. Bleary eyed. Toschi sits in front. Looking just as bad.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: Your number one priority is the kids - you hear shots, you get them down, lean on the horn and keep driving. You drive on the rims till you get to a populated area, then duck and cover. On the drivers. Shell shocked. Toschi rubs his brow.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I know you didn't sign up for this, but we're doing everything we can-—

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN BUS DRIVER
dialogues.text: Like what? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 69 70 71 FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 50.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Toschi surprised. A large WOMAN BUS DRIVER in the third r

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN BUS DRIVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I got two kids too scared to go near the windows in our house much less to school. What are you doing for them? A general MURMURING of support from the other drivers. Toschi, shocked into silence.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN BUS DRIVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That's what I thought. C'mon, Johnny. The Woman and several others rise to leave in disgust. Toschi, watching them go. Paralyzed. Finally...

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: We're gonna catch this guy. We're gonna catch him and put him away. He means it. The Woman sees this in his eyes. She and the others retake their seats.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Monday, October 20, 1969. Graysmith, driving David to school. Stonefaced. David, watching him. Neither speaks. Both scared. As we hear a PLANE SOAR overhead...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Avery, working at his desk. The TV playing continuous NEW FOOTAGE OF THE BUSES. A shadow falls over him. Graysmith.

dialogues.speaker: AVERY
dialogues.text: (not looking up) I believe we discussed the looming-

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: (conspiratorially) Do you think they've considered the water theory? Avery looks up at him.

dialogues.speaker: AVERY
dialogues.text: “Water theory"? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Geographically, every attack took place near a body of water, or a water based name. Lake Herman Road, Blue Rock Springs Road, and Lake Berryessa-

dialogues.speaker: AVERY
dialogues.text: Waaaash-ington and Cherry?

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: You think?

dialogues.speaker: AVERY
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: I'm looking for patterns. I've been reading this book "Homicide Investigations" by Lemoyne Snyder? He says you always look for patterns—

dialogues.speaker: AVERY
dialogues.text: No. You can't think of this case in normal police terms.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Why not? Avery stares at him. He's not going away. Avery sighs and motions for Graysmith to sit.

dialogues.speaker: AVERY
dialogues.text: Consider the fingerprint. You have four crime scenes - Solano, Vallejo, Berryessa, and here. No usable prints at the first three or on the letters...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The print man BILL HAMLET sits at a folding table with a magnifying glass, going through prints on 3X5 cards as To and Armstrong look on, frustrated.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: How does our master criminal suddenly come to the city and leave a bloody latent? I mean, assuming the gloves are his, he shoots the cabbie, then takes them off?  FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 52.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: So it's not his print?

dialogues.speaker: AVERY
dialogues.text: Maybe, maybe not, but that's not the point. The first attack-

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: David Farraday and Betty Lou Jensen.

dialogues.speaker: AVERY
dialogues.text: Both die, but from there on out, he only manages to kill the girls.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Not for lack of trying.

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: Mageau lives, Ferrin dies. Hartnell lives, Shepard dies. He gets so caught up with the women, he forgets to finish off the men.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: Plus, they're all couples, all lovers lanes.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Paul Stine's not...

dialogues.speaker: AVERY
dialogues.text: Exactly. A beat. Graysmith getting it:

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: A single male cab driver killed at Washington and Cherry doesn't fit.

dialogues.speaker: AVERY
dialogues.text: So why did Zodiac kill him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toschi turns to Armstrong, realizing: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 76 77 78 FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 53.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: He's breaking the pattern.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: October 22, 1969. Asleep. The phone again. Toschi reaches for the light, it's not there. Picks up.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Someone claiming to be Zodiac called Oakland P.D. a half hour ago. He says he's gonna call in on Jim Dunbar's morning show. He wants either F. Lee Bailey or Melvin Belli on to counsel him.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: On television?

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: In three hours.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: We better go wake up Melvin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toschi drives, Armstrong sits shotgun. Exhausted.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: Animal crackers?

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: Glovebox. A VOICE from the floor of the backseat:

dialogues.speaker: BELLI, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Are these windows bulletproof? We realize Belli is already in the car, hiding in back.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: Yes, Melvin. Armstrong gives him a look - Toschi shakes his head "no".

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You don't have to lie on the floor. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BELLI, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: This man is a marksman. He could snuff me out at a moment's notice.

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: Are you sure you're up to this?

dialogues.speaker: BELLI, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Don't you worry, Inspector, I'll be fine when the lights come on. This man asked for my help.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: You mean the man you're worried about snuffing you.

dialogues.speaker: BELLI, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: What are these, cookies? Dear Lord, man, do you ever clean this car? As they turn into the KGO TELEVISION PARKING LOT. The entrance, swarming with REPORTERS.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: Shit.

dialogues.speaker: BELLI, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (panicked) Good God, what?

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: KGO must've tipped other stations. FLASHBULBS go off as they pull up. Immediately, the cheerfully rotund attorney with a foppish fashion sense p up from the floor, ready for the limelight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: While Toschi speaks to the DIRECTOR in the glass control booth, Armstrong stands briefing Belli and host JIM DUNBA both are being miked up for the broadcast.

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: Get him talking, convince him to meet you somewhere. If you see an opportunity, we want you to suggest Old St. Mary's Church in Chinatown.

dialogues.speaker: DUNBAR
dialogues.text: You'll be tracing the call? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 79 80 81 82 FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 55.

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: Pacific Telephone says you have to keep him on for fifteen minutes.

dialogues.speaker: BELLI
dialogues.text: We can do that, can't we Jim? Dunbar doesn't look as convinced.

dialogues.speaker: DIRECTOR, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Sixty seconds! Clear the set!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Graysmith and David, sitting. Graysmith, turning on the T Flips the channel to the CHANNEL 7 - DUNBAR sits facing B and converses to the camera.

dialogues.speaker: DUNBAR
dialogues.text: Welcome to this special edition of our show in which we're joined by attorney Melvin Belli who the Zodiac Killer personally requested to appear...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Avery and other reporters, in early to watch. Shorty sits with them. Avery opens a pad, ready to write.

dialogues.speaker: DUNBAR
dialogues.text: So, the phone lines are open, Mr. Belli is here-

dialogues.speaker: BELLI
dialogues.text: Here to help, Jim.

dialogues.speaker: DUNBAR
dialogues.text: Yes, here to help, and we ask the public not to call in so that the Zodiac himself can reach us...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through the glass we see Belli and Dunbar chatter banally waiting for the call. Toschi, checking his watch. JOLTED when the PHONE RINGS. The booth erupts.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: Roll the tape, get the tape- A reel to reel tape recorder hooked to the phone is activated. The DIRECTOR shushes them as in the studio...

dialogues.speaker: BELLI
dialogues.text: Hello? Silence.

dialogues.speaker: BELLI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hello, this is Melvin Belli. Who am I speaking with? Just the HISS of an open phone line. We pan through the booth. Everyone on the edge of their seats...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Graysmith and David watching.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: This is the Zodiac speaking. A chill goes up Graysmith's spine...

dialogues.speaker: BELLI
dialogues.text: Is there something I can call you that's a little less ominous? A long beat. Then:

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: "Sam".

dialogues.speaker: BELLI
dialogues.text: Sam, is there somewhere we can meet and talk about this?

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Meet me on top of the Fairmont hotel. Without anyone else or I'll jump!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toschi scoops up a phone. Speaking rapidly.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: I need a unit at the Fairmont Hotel... 56. 83 84 85 86  87 88 89 90 FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 57.

dialogues.speaker: BELLI
dialogues.text: Sam?

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: BELLI
dialogues.text: Do you think you need medical care?

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Medical, not mental.

dialogues.speaker: BELLI
dialogues.text: Do you have health problems?

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I'm sick. I have headaches.

dialogues.speaker: BELLI
dialogues.text: I have headaches too, but a chiropractor stopped them a week ago. I think I can help you- CLICK. "Sam" hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: He knows they're tracing his calls...
