dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Avery, scribbling, trying to get down ever word.

dialogues.speaker: DUNBAR, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Sam, we'd like you to know that we are not tracing these calls. It's a long, difficult process and ineffective with these short calls- The PHONE RINGS AGAIN.

dialogues.speaker: BELLI
dialogues.text: Sam? A beat. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Uh-huh?

dialogues.speaker: BELLI
dialogues.text: Sam, we're not tracing your calls. Sam - You have my word. Through the glass, Toschi gives him a thumbs-up.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: BELLI
dialogues.text: Sam, you need to tell me what your problem is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Avery, Shorty, and the Reporters, watching.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: I don't want to go to the gas chamber. I have headaches. If I kill, I don't get them.

dialogues.speaker: SHORTY
dialogues.text: That's fucked up.

dialogues.speaker: BELLI
dialogues.text: You want to live, don't you, Sam? Well this is your passport. How long have you been having these headaches?

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Since I killed a kid. A beat as everyone takes this in.

dialogues.speaker: BELLI
dialogues.text: Do you have blackouts?

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: BELLI
dialogues.text: Do you have fits?

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: No. I just have headaches. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 92 FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 59.

dialogues.speaker: DUNBAR
dialogues.text: Did you attempt to call one other time when Mr. Bailey was with us two or three weeks ago?

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: DUNBAR
dialogues.text: Why did you want to talk to Mr. Bailey-

dialogues.speaker: BELLI
dialogues.text: Why do you want to talk to me?

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I don't want to be hurt. I don't want to go to the gas chamber.

dialogues.speaker: BELLI
dialogues.text: You're not going to be hurt if you talk to me.

dialogues.speaker: DUNBAR
dialogues.text: You're not going to the gas chamber.

dialogues.speaker: BELLI
dialogues.text: I wouldn't think that they'd ask for capital punishment. We should ask the district attorney - you want me to do that, Sam? You want me to talk to the district attorney? Over the phone, we hear a SMALL SCREAM.

dialogues.speaker: DUNBAR
dialogues.text: (panicked) What was that, Sam?

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I did not say anything.

dialogues.speaker: BELLI
dialogues.text: We heard a scream. In a small voice:

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: That was my headache.

dialogues.speaker: BELLI
dialogues.text: You sound like you're in a great deal of pain- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: My head aches. I'm so sick... Another SCREAM. Belli jumps this time.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I'm going to kill them! I'm going to kill all those kids! CLICK. Another hang up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Graysmith shuts off the TV. David, in a small voice:

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Do I have to go to school today?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Avery looks down at his scribbled notes.

dialogues.speaker: AVERY
dialogues.text: I gotta file this. He races out of the room....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toschi exhales.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: Hell....

dialogues.speaker: DUNBAR, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Our lines are still open, Sam, and we ask you to please call back...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INSERT - Avery, typing: POTENTIAL ZODIAC CALLS TELEVI-

dialogues.speaker: HYMAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Paul, he's back on! Avery leaps up and books back to the TV to see...

dialogues.speaker: BELLI, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (on TV) Sam, what do you want us to do?  97 98 99 100 FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 61.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I feel awful lonesomeness.

dialogues.speaker: BELLI
dialogues.text: We should meet and talk. Just us.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: BELLI
dialogues.text: How about Old St. Mary's Church in Chinatown?

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: No, I pick. In front of the Daly City St. Vincent De Paul at 10:30.

dialogues.speaker: BELLI
dialogues.text: I'll see you there. Take care of yourself, Sam. CLICK. He's gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toschi scooping up the phone:

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: I need an address in Daly City...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A HUGE CONVOY of POLICE CARS scream through the streets. Following them are at least SIX NEWS VANS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Armstrong drives. Toschi sits shotgun.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: There is no way this guy shows. They pull up to the St. Vincent De Paul. Getting out...  101 102 FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 62.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cops everywhere. Helicopters circle. In the midst of it a is a smiling Belli. He looks to Toschi and Armstrong.

dialogues.speaker: BELLI
dialogues.text: You gents put on quite the secret meeting! We PULL BACK from the scene to take in all the hub-bub...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A REEL TO REEL TAPE - Playing back the television program BRYAN HARTNELL, the survivor from Berryessa. Listening.

dialogues.speaker: BRYAN
dialogues.text: It's not him. Voice is too high, too young. Toschi shuts off the tape.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: Thanks for coming down. Bryan nods and gets to his feet. It's a slow, agonizing process because of his wounds. Armstrong goes to help...

dialogues.speaker: BRYAN
dialogues.text: I got it. Armstrong steps back. Bryan finally manages to straighten and grips a cane. He slowly hobbles out of the booth. Toschi watches him go. Pained. Once he's out of earshot:

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: They pulled off the trace. Our Daly City no-show called from a mental institution. Toschi snorts.

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The operator from Oakland PD is sure the man who called her had a deeper voice. Calmer. (pause) Could've actually been him.  103 FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 63.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: November 10, 1969. Graysmith, stepping off the elevator t find... The room is practically DESERTED. That can only mean one thing. He drops his briefcase and RUNS. Headed for the Editorial Room. Rounds a corner to find it PACKED WITH PEOPLE. Theiriot's faint voice in the center:

dialogues.speaker: THEIRIOT, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: «SO I shall change my way of collecting slaves. I shall no longer announce to anyone when I commit my murders, they shall look like routine robberies, killings of anger and a few fake accidents, etcetera. Graysmith politely tries to get through the throng toward the table. Not wanting to jostle anyone. ANOTHER REPORTER whispering, filling Graysmith in:

dialogues.speaker: THEIRIOT, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: The police shall never catch Two new letters, me because I have been too mailed a day apart... clever for them. One - I look like the description passed out only when I do my thing, the rest of the time I look entirely different. I shall not tell you what my disguise consists of when I kill. Two - as of yet I have left no fingerprints behind contrary to what the police say about me, I wear transparent finger tips. All it is is two coats of airplane cement coated on my finger tips... Graysmith reaches the table. Theiriot, ringed by Avery, Hyman, Peck, Toschi and Armstrong.

dialogues.speaker: THEIRIOT, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: .--I enjoy needling the blue pigs. Hey, blue pig, I was in the park, you were using firetrucks to mask the sound of your cruising prowl cars. Close on TOSCHI'S FACE. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 103 104 105 FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 64.

dialogues.speaker: THEIRIOT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hey, pig, doesn't it rile you up to have your nose rubbed in your booboos? If you cops think I'm going to take on a bus the way I stated I was, you deserve to have holes in your heads- (flips the page) Oh, no.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: Let me see. He takes the pages. One - a crudely sketched DIAGRAM. Toschi examines it as Armstrong takes the letter:

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: Take one bag of ammonium nitrate fertilizer, and one gallon of stove oil, and dump a few bags of gravel on top- It's a bomb.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: Somebody needs to call the army and see if this Rube Goldberg contraption could actually work.

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: Dave, take a look at this. He's opened the dripping pen card to reveal - A HUGE NEW CIPHER. Avery blinks. Looks across the table to see Graysmith...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Graysmith sits with Avery. Finally allowed in to the inne circle. On the table - whiskey for Avery and a HUGE BLUE UMBRELLA DRINK for Graysmith. As he sips it:

dialogues.speaker: AVERY
dialogues.text: So, tell me about yourself. You married?

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Divorced. Two kids.

dialogues.speaker: AVERY
dialogues.text: What do you do for fun? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 64a.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Well... I like to read... I enjoy books...

dialogues.speaker: AVERY
dialogues.text: Those are the same things. (leaning forward) (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: AVERY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Why have you been going through my trash? Graysmith doesn't respond. Looking guilty.

dialogues.speaker: AVERY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How'd you know he was going to send another code?

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: I guessed.

dialogues.speaker: AVERY
dialogues.text: You guessed.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: The first code was too easy.

dialogues.speaker: AVERY
dialogues.text: This can no longer be ignored - what is this you're drinking?

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: You wouldn't make fun of my drink if you tried it. Avery, breaking. He takes the drink. Takes a sip and...

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: GRAYSMITH AND AVERY - Later. Now both have huge blue drinks. Both buzzed now, the new code in front of them. H removes a vial of coke from his coat. Taps some into a di Rolling the tip of an unlit cigarette in it.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Who actually cracked the code? A married couple who like puzzles. So what does that say about Zodiac?

dialogues.speaker: AVERY
dialogues.text: He's no expert.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Right. The first one was just a substitution code like the kind we all did as Boy Scouts, A is 1, B is 2, and so on-

dialogues.speaker: AVERY
dialogues.text: We weren't all Boy Scouts. Graysmith pulls a rumpled copy of the FIRST CIPHER from h pocket and spreads it out on the table. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: It looks hard, but you just have to know where to start-

dialogues.speaker: AVERY
dialogues.text: You actually carry that around with you?

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: AVERY
dialogues.text: (smiling) No reason.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: What is the most common double consonant in the English language?

dialogues.speaker: AVERY
dialogues.text: Consonant?

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: The double L. And what's the one word we know Zodiac will use in here?

dialogues.speaker: AVERY
dialogues.text: "Kill".

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Exactly, so the Hardens start looking for double symbols which they find here, here, and here - each with the same two symbols preceding them. Now they've got a repeating four letter word ending with two symbols they assume stand for "L"-

dialogues.speaker: AVERY
dialogues.text: (getting into it) And since they think the whole word is "Kill"-

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: That gives them the symbols for "K" and "I". And they're on their way.

dialogues.speaker: AVERY
dialogues.text: So how does someone go from A is 1 and B is 2 to this? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 105 106 FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 67.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: The same way I did. He goes to the library. Graysmith opens his briefcase and pulls out a STACK of LIBRARY BOOKS. Holds up the first one.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: "The Codebreakers". In the preface, the author presents a simple substitution alphabet. 8 of the 26 symbols he suggests were in the first Zodiac cipher.

dialogues.speaker: AVERY
dialogues.text: What about other symbols? The medieval looking ones?

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: I thought they looked medieval too. Then I found a cipher used during the Middle Ages in here. (pulls a second book) Guess what the cipher was called. The Zodiac Alphabet. A beat. Avery takes the book. Looks at the page. The Zodiac Alphabet sits there, many symbols identical to the First Code. Avery, lights the cigarette. Taking Graysmith in.

dialogues.speaker: AVERY
dialogues.text: Jesus, kid... What do you want out of this?

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: What? Nothing-

dialogues.speaker: AVERY
dialogues.text: What's your angle? This is good business for everyone but you.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: How can you call this business?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toschi, up late. Staring at the letter. Big band plays on the phonograph. He absently munches animal crackers as he rereads the lines over again: What you do not know is whether the death machine is at the sight or whether it is being stored in my basement for future use (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 106 107 108 FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 68.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI'S WIFE
dialogues.text: Come to bed. He looks up at her. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: I have to make a call. He picks up the phone and dials. She heads for the bedroo On the other end, groggy:

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: Not many people have basements in California-

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: “Basement for future use", yeah. I'll have Vallejo and Napa check with their city planners. Get some sleep. Toschi looks to the bedroom. Then back to the letter. No chance of that tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: December 29, 1969. Bleary eyed, Toschi and Armstrong clim the steps to Belli's richly appointed residence.

dialogues.speaker: BELLI, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (overly dramatic) Dear Melvin, this... Is the Zodiac speaking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Close on Toschi and Armstrong, pad out, taking notes. Bel across from them, reading the newest ZODIAC LETTER.

dialogues.speaker: BELLI
dialogues.text: I wish you a happy Christmass. The one thing I ask of you is this, please help me. I cannot reach out for help because this thing in me won't let me. WIDEN to show that Belli has called the police there in t middle of a DINNER PARTY. The hoi palloi of San Francisco stand behind Toschi and Armstrong, gasping at Belli's dramatic reading of the letter he just received. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Belli pauses as his HOUSEKEEPER delivers a hot toddy.

dialogues.speaker: BELLI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Thank you. (clears his throat) I am finding it extremely difficult to hold it in check I am afraid I will loose control again and take my ninth & possibly tenth victim

dialogues.speaker: SOCIETY WOMAN
dialogues.text: Melvin, he's reaching out to you!

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: Poor fellow.

dialogues.speaker: BELLI
dialogues.text: Inspectors, he sent the letter directly to my residence instead of the papers. It's a cry for help, intended as a private communique.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: Which is why you contacted the press.

dialogues.speaker: BELLI
dialogues.text: The people have a right to know. (offering) Toddy?

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: When did the letter arrive?

dialogues.speaker: BELLI
dialogues.text: In the last week. I was away for the holiday, on safari. What did you gentlemen do for Christmas?

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: You're looking at it.

dialogues.speaker: BELLI
dialogues.text: You must see Africa. The cradle of civilization. Fascinating people. Beautiful. Savages. Murmurs of agreement from the partygoers.

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: Back to the killer who wrote you? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BELLI
dialogues.text: Yes, of course. It's my belief he only penned this letter because he couldn't get through to me on the Dunbar show or here.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: He called here?

dialogues.speaker: BELLI
dialogues.text: Several times. I was out, but he spoke with my housekeeper. Didn't leave a number.

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: He's crafty like that. Mind if I ask her some questions?

dialogues.speaker: BELLI
dialogues.text: Not at all, though the real story is the letter.

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: I'll be back. He exits to go look for the housekeeper. Belli, focusing attention on Toschi.

dialogues.speaker: BELLI
dialogues.text: This is a window into this man's soul. Killing is his compulsion - though he tries to ignore it, it drives him. It's in his blood.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: Could be. Or maybe he just likes attention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: March 22, 1970. Outside Modesto. Late. A lone duster of a SEDAN rattles down the highway, the only car in sight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KATHLEEN JOHNS at the wheel. Sweet face, 30's. Changes lanes. From nowhere, HEADLIGHTS are suddenly behind her. Kathleen signals. Changing lanes so the HEADLIGHTS can pa They don't. They pull up behind her. FLASHING NOW. Kathleen keeps driving. The other driver becomes more insistent. HONKING. Motioning for her to pull over. Finally she does. Pulling to a halt on the SHOULDER of th road. The other car pulls in behind her. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: And as it does, we TILT to see... Kathleen's SLEEPING BAB the seat next to her. A MAN walks up. WE DON'T SEE HIS FACE. Kathleen, nervous. Thinking maybe this wasn't the best idea. She reaches to put the car back in gear when:

dialogues.speaker: THE MAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (apologetic) I hope I didn't scare you. Your right wheel is loose. Kathleen relaxes. Feeling dumb for being scared.

dialogues.speaker: KATHLEEN
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: THE MAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I could tighten the lugs for you.

dialogues.speaker: KATHLEEN
dialogues.text: Would you?

dialogues.speaker: THE MAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Can't be too careful. He goes back to his car and retrieves a LUG WRENCH. Kneel down behind her back tire, out of sight. He's down there long time. Kathleen checks her rearview. Can't see him. Just as she's getting nervous again....

dialogues.speaker: THE MAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: All done. She turns, he's STANDING by the passenger door.

dialogues.speaker: KATHLEEN
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: THE MAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: No problem. Have a good night. He walks away. Kathleen, watching him go back to his own car. He gets behind the wheel. Starts back up. Headlights on. Puts the car in gear. Pulls back onto the highway. Passing her. She watches his tail lights go. She puts her own car in drive and pulls out... She only gets fifty yards when her RIGHT WHEEL CRUNCHES O the axle in a SHOWER OF SPARKS! The baby, waking, CRYING. Kathleen fights for control, wrenching the wheel right, managing to pilot it to the shoulder. Kathleen, breathing hard. Picks up her baby. Trying to quiet him. Through the windshield, we see THE MAN'S CAR SLOWLY PULL A U-TURN. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 111 FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 72.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The headlights, coming back. She's too involved with baby notice until:

dialogues.speaker: THE MAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Are you okay? She JUMPS at his voice. He's pulled alongside her.

dialogues.speaker: KATHLEEN
dialogues.text: Yeah, I- Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: THE MAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Must've been worse than I thought. I could give you a lift toa service station. Kathleen looks back to her tire. Makes a decision. Gather up her baby and gets out of the car.

dialogues.speaker: THE MAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I didn't know you had a baby. Kathleen stops.

dialogues.speaker: KATHLEEN
dialogues.text: Is that a problem? A long beat...

dialogues.speaker: THE MAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: The more the merrier.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trash everywhere. Kathleen slides into the passenger seat Her baby on her lap. They pull onto the highway. Riding i silence. Quite fast. The baby, crying. Kathleen uncomfortable. She lights a cigarette. Smokes a little. Still the man doesn't speak. She stubs the butt out nervously. Finally sees a GAS STATION coming up. Relieved. But the M doesn't slow down. THEY PASS IT.

dialogues.speaker: KATHLEEN
dialogues.text: I think you passed a gas station.

dialogues.speaker: THE MAN
dialogues.text: It was closed. She looks at him. Tries to regroup. They're SPEEDING UP. Doing near 70. The Man CRANKS DOWN his WINDOW. Howling ai fills the car. Kathleen's Baby WHINES at the cold. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 112 113 FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 73.

dialogues.speaker: KATHLEEN
dialogues.text: Shhhhhh. It's okay. Mommy's here. The Man looks over at her.

dialogues.speaker: THE MAN
dialogues.text: Before I kill you, I'm going to throw your baby out the window. Kathleen blinks. Did he just say...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A WOMAN drives Highway 132. Listening to music. A BIG RIG stopped ahead. The DRIVER in the middle of the road PLEAD with a HYSTERICAL WOMAN. She pulls over...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Woman gets out of her car. Before she can even ask

dialogues.speaker: TRUCK DRIVER
dialogues.text: She was on the side of the road! The hysterical woman is KATHLEEN and she's SCREAMING BLOO MURDER. Face cut bloody from jumping from the car. Gravel in her hair. And no baby in sight.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: What happened? What he do to you?

dialogues.speaker: TRUCK DRIVER
dialogues.text: I didn't do nothing, lady! I found her like this- Kathleen, gasping and weeping as she tries to form words

dialogues.speaker: KATHLEEN
dialogues.text: Muh-muh-muh-

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: What? What is it? It'll be okay-

dialogues.speaker: KATHLEEN
dialogues.text: (through sobs) He said- my baby-

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Your baby? (to the Driver) Where's her baby? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 114 115 FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 74.

dialogues.speaker: TRUCK DRIVER
dialogues.text: She didn't have one when I stopped-

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Where's your baby? Still weeping, Kathleen turns and begins to STUMBLE AWAY them. Heading for the side of the road. The Driver pales.

dialogues.speaker: TRUCK DRIVER
dialogues.text: Oh, Jesus... The Woman, following her and we do to, as Kathleen slides down the embankment and pushes some tall grass aside and Her baby lies there. Perfectly fine. Safe. Alive.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: You hid him?

dialogues.speaker: KATHLEEN
dialogues.text: In- In case he came back...

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: This is the Zodiac speaking... Toschi and Armstrong, getting out of their car. Walking toward the Chronicle's entrance...

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: By the way have you cracked the last cipher I sent you? As they push through the FRONT DOORS...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: April 28, 1970. MATCH TO - Toschi and Armstrong entering lobby. WEARING DIFFERENT CLOTHES. A different day.

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: This is the Zodiac speaking... They step into the elevator...

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I would like to see some nice Zodiac buttons wandering about town... The elevator doors close - DING!  116 117 FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 75.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: June 26, 1970. DING! The elevator doors open - Toschi and Armstrong in a THIRD SET of clothes. Another day.

dialogues.speaker: AVERY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: This is the Zodiac speaking... Walking briskly to the Editorial Room...

dialogues.speaker: AVERY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I shot a man sitting in a parked car with a .38. As Graysmith watches, they close the door.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: This is the Zodiac speaking...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: July 24, 1970. Graysmith reading a copy of the newest let aloud:

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: So now I have a little list, beginning with the woman and her baby that I gave a rather interesting ride for a couple hours one evening a few months back that ended in my burning her car where I found them- (puts down the letter) We're really not going to run anymore of his letters? He looks over to Avery who slugs back a shot. Quite drunk

dialogues.speaker: AVERY
dialogues.text: Our brothers in blue want us to hold off. To see how he "reacts".

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Four letters in three months and he doesn't mention Kathleen Johns till now...

dialogues.speaker: AVERY
dialogues.text: That's because he's full of shit.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: What do you mean? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 118 FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 76.

dialogues.speaker: AVERY
dialogues.text: You don't know? He gets to his feet. Unsteady.

dialogues.speaker: AVERY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'll show you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dark. The stacks, deserted. Keys in the door. Lights come on. Avery weaves into the room, leading Graysmith.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: I don't think we're supposed to be in here-

dialogues.speaker: AVERY
dialogues.text: That's why I have keys, Robert. I am a man with keys. Pull the Modesto Bee from March for me. I'm gonna sit and smoke. Graysmith goes. Avery, true to his word, sits and lights Graysmith's voice, from the stacks:

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: What am I looking for!

dialogues.speaker: AVERY
dialogues.text: Kathleen Johns! Also, grab the Chron from- Never mind, I'll find it!

dialogues.speaker: TIME CUT TO
dialogues.text: 118A BOOM! Avery drops a copy of the Chronicle on the tab to the Modesto Bee.

dialogues.speaker: AVERY
dialogues.text: Okay, look at the letter again. The part about Kathleen Johns. What facts does he give?

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Woman and her baby abducted... car set on fire...

dialogues.speaker: AVERY
dialogues.text: Now read the article from the Bee. Graysmith begins reading an article entitled "WOMAN ESCAP FROM ZODIAC". (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: AVERY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Seeing it yet?

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Everything in the letter was already printed in the paper.

dialogues.speaker: AVERY
dialogues.text: He's done it before. Holds up the Chronicle. A FRONT PAGE STORY about a police officer shooting.

dialogues.speaker: AVERY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Officer Richard Radietch, shot sitting in his car.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Zodiac said he shot someone in their car-

dialogues.speaker: AVERY
dialogues.text: Couple days after this article came out. Police already have somebody in custody. Zodiac didn't do it, but he took credit anyway. He's in it for the press. (drunken grin) He's constructing an image. Shit, he even stole his symbol.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: What? On Avery. Realizing he might have said too much.

dialogues.speaker: AVERY
dialogues.text: If I tell you something, will you promise not to tell anyone else?

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Who am I going to tell?

dialogues.speaker: AVERY
dialogues.text: Totally solid point. Okay. He pulls a piece of paper from his pocket and hands it to Graysmith, who unfolds it.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: It's a magazine ad for a watch- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: AVERY
dialogues.text: A Zodiac watch. Look at the face. Graysmith does. And right in the center of the watch face the GUNSIGHT ZODIAC SYMBOL.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Oh, my goodness...

dialogues.speaker: AVERY
dialogues.text: That's right. I think it's only place that word and that symbol have ever appeared together before the letters. Guy stole his logo off a watch.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Why would someone who's killed thirteen people do that?

dialogues.speaker: AVERY
dialogues.text: Claims he's killed thirteen people. But which ones can we actually confirm? The three in Vallejo, the one at Berryessa, the cabbie and that's it. (off his look) Bobby... you almost look disappointed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: October 11, 1970. TOSCHI and ARMSTRONG. Sitting. We don't know where. Toschi munches animal crackers.

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: Chief's pulling everyone off the buses. Business as usual.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: Something will shake loose.

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: Not a peep in four months. First he can't shut up and now...

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: Maybe we drove him underground.

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: Maybe he's gone. Toschi reaches down for another cracker. The box is empty (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: Happy Birthday.

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: Thanks. Toschi puts the car in drive...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and we realize they've been sitting vigil at the Stine scene. We hold on the corner as the two men drive away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: October 28, 1970. Graysmith in a chipper mood, buying a c of coffee from SHORTY.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Does it ever bother you that people call you "Shorty"?

dialogues.speaker: SHORTY
dialogues.text: Does it ever bother you that people call you "retard"?

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Nobody calls me that. Shorty just stares at him. Confused, Graysmith walks over Avery, who's sorting through his MAIL and watching the TV the wall, which plays a PRESS CONFERENCE.

dialogues.speaker: CANDIDATE
dialogues.text: (on TV) I believe some clues were overlooked in the murder of Darlene Ferrin...

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Who's that?

dialogues.speaker: AVERY
dialogues.text: Florence Douglas, mayor of Vallejo. She's running for governor. He opens one letter. Bill. Tosses it.

dialogues.speaker: CANDIDATE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: In the last year we have received ten pieces of correspondence from the Zodiac, and still are no closer as to his identity... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: AVERY
dialogues.text: And sayonara police endorsement! Good work, Flo. Another letter. Junk. Tosses it.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Does anybody ever call me names?

dialogues.speaker: AVERY
dialogues.text: You mean like retard?

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: AVERY
dialogues.text: No. Another letter. Opens it. He STOPS COLD. Graysmith doesn' notice. Still watching the television.

dialogues.speaker: AVERY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh, my God... The sound of all Avery's letters, FALLING TO THE FLOOR. Graysmith turns to see... A BLOODY PIECE OF PAUL STINE'S SHIRT. Fallen from an envelope that bears Avery's name.

dialogues.speaker: AVERY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I touched it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Avery, Toschi, Armstrong, Peck, and Hyman sit, a GREETING CARD between them. SKELETON on the front.

dialogues.speaker: HYMAN
dialogues.text: Paul, we didn't run his last letters. You wrote the bulk of the Zodiac articles. It's only natural for him to get frustrated and try and communicate with you-

dialogues.speaker: AVERY
dialogues.text: Fuck "communicate" Read that. The front reads: FROM YOUR SECRET PAL. Below that is a printed verse. Toschi reads aloud: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: I feel it in my bones, you ache to know my name, and so I'll clue you in... Uses the tweezers to open the card. Finishing the rhyme:

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: .--But then why spoil our game! Boo! Happy Halloween! Inside the card - another skeleton, pasted from a differe card and sketches of EYES PEERING OUT. Below that:

dialogues.speaker: PEEK-A-BOO
dialogues.text: Silence as they stare at it.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Didn't you call him a "latent homosexual" in one of your articles? Avery raps his fist on the table.

dialogues.speaker: AVERY
dialogues.text: I want a gun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BOOM! BOOM! BOOM! On a target as the bullets miss it completely. Avery finishes emptying a HUGE GUN. Graysmith stands next to him, holding a newspaper. Reading aloud:

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: "...Paul Avery's investigation has earned him a message from the Zodiac himself warning - "You are Doomed". As a result, several Chron Newsman are wearing lapel buttons reading I Am Not Paul Avery'." Graysmith lowers the paper. Revealing HE WEARS ONE OF THE BUTTONS. Avery lowers his gun and we see he WEARS ONE TOO

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You should really be selling these. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 122 123 124 FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 82.

dialogues.speaker: AVERY
dialogues.text: (reloading) It's been a windfall since they published the threat on my life. This one guy won't stop writing. I'm gonna meet him tonight down south in "Riverside". You want to tag along?

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Tonight? I kind of have a date. Avery raises his eyebrows, reloading.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Who's this tipster?

dialogues.speaker: AVERY
dialogues.text: He wishes to remain anonymous. I, of course, wish to remain infamous, so we're gonna get along great. He turns and UNLOADS THE GUN again. DEAFENING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Using a newspaper as an umbrella, Graysmith hurries throu light rain to a RESTAURANT. Late for his date...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Graysmith enters, soaked. Late. Fumbles his way up to the table where his date is sipping wine. Her name is MELANIE

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: You must be Melanie.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: Which would make you Robert.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: It would. Glynnis told me a lot about you- Oh, good, you already have wine.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: I do.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: I'm so sorry, how late am I- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: Just a few minutes. I only just got here- He knocks over a GLASS. Grabs a napkin, dabs up the spill

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Sorry - I mean, good. Traffic was terrible, I was at a gun range.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: Glynnis said you were a cartoonist, what were you doing at a gun range?

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Reading. I think I need more napkins- (as he sits) So, you work with Glynnis?

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: For her, actually.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: She seems very nice but my kids are afraid of her-

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: Me too. So, the gun range?

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: I'm kind of helping out on - you know the Zodiac?

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Do you know who Paul Avery is?

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: Why does that sound familiar?

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: He's the writer Zodiac threatened.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: Yes, I saw that on TV.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Well, I work near him - he's following a lead tonight. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 124 FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 84.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He went down to Riverside to meet an anonymous tipster. Where is Riverside?

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: I think it's near L.A.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: You know, I don't think he knows it's that far. She laughs. He smiles.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: It sounds dangerous.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Yeah. What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: Well, it's an anonymous tip, right?

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Yes...

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: So it could be an ambush. It could be Zodiac. Seems kind of stupid.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Yes, well... Paul has a gun.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: Oh. Okay. A beat. Melanie picks up her menu.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So, what's good here?

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: (looking around) Uhhh, I've never been here before. The spaghetti? A WAITER appears.

dialogues.speaker: WAITER
dialogues.text: Are you ready to order? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: Yes... I'll have the penne vodka, but could you do it in a cream sauce?

dialogues.speaker: WAITER
dialogues.text: Of course. And you, sir? She looks - he hasn't picked up his menu. Preoccupied.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: (to the waiter) Could you give us another minute? The Waiter departs. Instead of looking at the menu, Graysmith begins searching his pockets.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: You don't have any change, do you? I don't have any- Wait. (pulls a coin out) No, that's a penny.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: Do you need to make a phone call?

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Well, when you said it was dangerous - I started thinking that's true, it is dangerous-

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: And stupid.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: So stupid, that's right. I want to call his wife to see if she's heard from him. Melanie stares at him. She picks up her purse.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: I have change.

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED 128
dialogues.text: 129 130 131 FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 86.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Graysmith and Melanie, huddled half in and out of a phone booth. Soaked as Graysmith feeds coins into the phone. Th dials. Rotary. It's taking forever.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Sorry. I'm sorry. It would be so much easier if we had wrist radios, wouldn't it?

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: I don't quite know how to answer that, Robert. He finishes dialing. Finally:

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: It's ringing. Hello? Mrs. Avery? Oh, Ms. St. James. But you are married to Paul Avery? Good. Oh, sorry, this is Robert Graysmith, from the Chronicle. Is everything all right? (pause) Well, no, of course everything should be all right. I didn't mean that it wasn't, I meant- I'm sure you're fine, everyone's fine. But, have you heard from Paul? (pause) I didn't mean you should have heard from him- No, it's not a bad thing, I just wanted to make sure he's, you know... alive. He winces at the response he gets...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Avery pulls up to a curb. Across the street, a fenced off old CAR WASH. He rechecks the address. This is it. He shuts the engine and gets out of the car. Crosses the street. Hops the fence. Approaching the dark building...

dialogues.speaker: AVERY
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Graysmith, hanging up the phone. He turns to Melanie. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 131 132 FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 87.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: She'll call when she hears from him.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: Good.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: (can't believe it) I actually have to go home. To wait for the call. Melanie stares at him.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: Is this some sleazy plan to get me to come back to your place?

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Oh, my goodness, no, I'm sorry-

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: I'll get the food to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Avery tries the glass door. Locked. Knocks. Nothing. Wipes some dirt off. Squints through. Nobody inside.

dialogues.speaker: AVERY
dialogues.text: Hello? I'm supposed to meet someone? No reply. Avery steps back. Collecting himself. He walks around the building. Comes to the car entrance.

dialogues.speaker: AVERY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hello? Is anyone in there? No response. Avery takes a few tentative steps in.

dialogues.speaker: AVERY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I got your letter? Still nothing. He fumbles out his gun. Waving it around i a terrible parody of a cop. More steps in.

dialogues.speaker: AVERY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I have a gun! MOVEMENT behind him. He whips around and points the shaky gun at A MAN STANDING THERE. An awkward moment. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: AVERY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hi. Paul Avery.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: That's not what your button says...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Graysmith, phone by his side. Up all night. Melanie curle up on the couch, still in her dress. She blinks awake.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: Anything?

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: No. You don't have to stay-

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: Are you kidding? This is the most interesting date I've ever had- THE PHONE RINGS. Graysmith, snatching it up:

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Paul?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Avery on the pay phone in the hallway. Through a door, we see SHERWOOD MORRILL examining something...

dialogues.speaker: AVERY
dialogues.text: You're not gonna believe this...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toschi entering to find the place in an uproar - phones ringing off the hook. Glares from other cops.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: What the hell is this?

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Dave, in here! Toschi looks - the voice came from  FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 89.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toschi finds Captain Lee and Armstrong watching a MORNING NEWSCAST on Lee's small portable black and white TV:

dialogues.speaker: NEWSCASTER
dialogues.text: (on TV) ...in a bizarre twist, the hunted has become hunter. Chronicle Reporter and Zodiac target Paul Avery claims to have uncovered new information regarding the only unsolved homicide in Riverside County's history - a 1966 Southern California murder that Avery now believes was the Zodiac's first victim.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN LEE
dialogues.text: He didn't call you about this?

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: (pointing at TV) Hang on. Now showing FOOTAGE of an INTERVIEW with Avery:

dialogues.speaker: AVERY
dialogues.text: (on TV) The Riverside killer wrote to the press letters that I took personally to the Office of Questioned Documents.

dialogues.speaker: INTERVIEWER
dialogues.text: (on TV) And what did this expert tell you?

dialogues.speaker: AVERY
dialogues.text: (on TV) What I knew in my gut, Ron. The handwriting matches Zodiac's...

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: How'd he get the evidence out of Riverside?

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: He took it to Sherwood without telling us, that son of a bitch... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Lee goes over and turns off the television.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN LEE
dialogues.text: You know how bad this looks?

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: We don't know how real the lead is-

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: It's very real. You know how I know? Because I saw it on TV. Silence. They know he's right.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN LEE
dialogues.text: Get on a plane, but keep it quiet. If it hits the press you're meeting in Riverside, it automatically confirms Avery's story, right or wrong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: November 16, 1970. Toschi finding his seat next to Narlow and MEL NICOLAI.

dialogues.speaker: NARLOW
dialogues.text: Dave, you know Mel Nicolai, he's working the case for Justice?

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: Good to see you, Mel.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLAI
dialogues.text: All due respect, can someone explain to me why I'm reading about breaks in this case in the Chronicle instead of getting calls from you?

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: They screwed us.

dialogues.speaker: NARLOW
dialogues.text: Dave, you do get your name in the paper a lot. People talk.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: I don't talk about open investigations period, Ken.

dialogues.speaker: PILOT, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Please prepare for departure... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Toschi leans back in his seat when a passing passenger cl him on the shoulder. AVERY, grinning:

dialogues.speaker: AVERY
dialogues.text: Dave! Narlow and Nicolai look on in disbelief.

dialogues.speaker: AVERY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Paul Avery, good to meet you, Paul Avery. Can I catch a ride with you gents when we land?

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: Not a good idea, Paul.

dialogues.speaker: AVERY
dialogues.text: I gotta take a cab? We're going to the same place- (off Toschi's look) Fair enough, fair enough. He heads a few rows back to his seat as Narlow and Nicola stare daggers at Toschi...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toschi, Narlow, and Nicolai shuffle into CAPTAIN IRV CROS office. Toschi, extending a hand.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: Thanks for seeing us, Captain.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN CROSS
dialogues.text: Not at all. You have some files for us?

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: I'll show you mine you show me yours.

dialogues.speaker: TIME CUT TO
dialogues.text: 138A Cross's desk, littered with files. He reads from his Book, by rote:

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN CROSS
dialogues.text: Cheri Jo Bates attended Riverside Community College. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN CROSS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Studying in the library the night of October 30, 1966, left with an unidentified male at closing - 9 P.M., body was found the next morning in the parking lot stabbed to death. Her car was disabled, someone pulled the distributor coil which caused the battery to die. The suspect shows up, offers to help-

dialogues.speaker: NARLOW
dialogues.text: Like Kathleen Johns?

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN CROSS
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: NARLOW
dialogues.text: A woman outside of Modesto, might be a Zodiac victim-

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: Might be. Her account's in, uhhhh, this file. He taps one of the many on Cross's desk.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN CROSS
dialogues.text: Okay - A typewritten confession was sent to the Riverside Press Enterprise November 29th, a month after Bates' murder. They ran it. He hands them copies. Narlow, reading:

dialogues.speaker: NARLOW
dialogues.text: "IT am not sick, I am insane, but that will not stop the game. This letter should be published for all to read"- He wants to publish, he calls it a game, sounds like our boy.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN CROSS
dialogues.text: Six months later, the police, the girl's father, and the paper all received these. He slides them a second letter, this one handscrawled:

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: Double postage, like Zodiac. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: NICOLAI
dialogues.text: These are what Sherwood Morrill matched to the Zodiac letters?

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN CROSS
dialogues.text: These and the desktop. Don? A Riverside Officer enters, carrying a small LIBRARY DESK

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN CROSS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This was found a couple months later in library storage. The cops crowd around it. The poem, carved into wood. Sick of living/ unwilling to die cut. Clean. If red/ clean. Blood spurting dripping Spilling; All over her new dress. Oh well, it was red anyway. Life draining into an uncertain death. She won't die. This time. Someone 11 find her just wait till next time. Rh

dialogues.speaker: NICOLAI
dialogues.text: Sherwood got a handwriting match off wood? Nobody carves in their true handwriting.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN CROSS
dialogues.text: Also, our letters and your letters, they don't bear much resemblance. He puts "Bates had to Die" next to the Paul Stine letter.

dialogues.speaker: NARLOW
dialogues.text: How did Paul Avery get the exemplars to give to Sherwood? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN CROSS
dialogues.text: I gave them to him. We spoke at length, and I told him we were meeting today.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: You told him?

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN CROSS
dialogues.text: Yes. I also told him we don't think this was Zodiac. Toschi blinks.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: Wait a minute-

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN CROSS
dialogues.text: We have a guy we like for it. Don't have enough to make it stick yet, but we're pretty sure it's him.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: If you don't think it's Zodiac, why did you give anything to Avery?

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN CROSS
dialogues.text: I'm trying to cooperate-

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: By giving information to reporters?

dialogues.speaker: NARLOW
dialogues.text: (trying to defuse) Look, I don't know from handwriting but Sherwood says it's a match, right? So maybe your guy did Cheri Jo, typed the confession, Zodiac saw it in the paper and wrote the letter to take credit. He's done that before.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN CROSS
dialogues.text: Look, you now have everything we have, but in my opinion? You all came south for nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toschi, Narlow, and Nicolai, leaving. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 139 FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 95.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLAI
dialogues.text: FUBAR, gentlemen. FUBAR.

dialogues.speaker: NARLOW
dialogues.text: I don't care what he says, this could still be 2.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: Problem is, the entire state already thinks it is. Narlow spies AVERY across the street, waiting for them.

dialogues.speaker: NARLOW
dialogues.text: Why don't you complain to your press agent? As Avery approaches, Narlow and Nicolai take off. Toschi deliberately moves in the other direction.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: Really don't want to talk to you right now, Paul-

dialogues.speaker: AVERY
dialogues.text: Dave, just a few questions-

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: Not now.

dialogues.speaker: AVERY
dialogues.text: It's news. I'm doing my job-

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: Well, now I can't do my job, Paul. We're already screwed with the amount of tips we get and you just freaked out the entire state!

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I've got Vallejo, Napa, and (as he writes) DOJ looking at me sideways, "'Out of the frying pan and Riverside telling me I'm ona into the fire' the normally snipe hunt and- cooperative lead inspector"- Toschi SLAPS the pad out of Avery's hand.

dialogues.speaker: AVERY
dialogues.text: Cheri Bates was a gift! You and Armstrong were never gonna find her- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: This may not be Zodiac. Does that matter to you? Does it matter that Riverside may not be able to make a case against their suspect?

dialogues.speaker: AVERY
dialogues.text: Tell that to Sherwood! I'm beating the bushes, trying to draw him out! We're in this together-

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: No, we're not in this together because I'm not worried about upping my circulation!

dialogues.speaker: AVERY TOSCHI
dialogues.text: He wrote me! He threatened Paul- my life!

dialogues.speaker: AVERY
dialogues.text: It's been a year and a half, Bullit, are gonna catch this fucking guy or not? Silence. Toschi, mad enough to spit.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: Fuck yourself Paul. You should've called me. He stalks away. Leaving Avery to pick up his pad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Graysmith, reading the morning paper - "ZODIAC RIVERSIDE CONNECTION CONFIRMED - by Paul Avery". He takes out a pai of scissors and begins clipping it for his files...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toschi, sitting with the same paper. The PHONES all aroun RINGING OFF THE HOOK. Armstrong, across from him.

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: Here comes Southern California...  143 144 145 146 147 FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 97.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An exhausted Toschi sits across from an INFORMANT. The latest in a countless string of interviews.

dialogues.speaker: INFORMANT 1
dialogues.text: I think my mailman is the Zodiac Killer... We begin a series of CUTS - DIFFERENT INFORMANTS, differe locations - talking to either Toschi or Armstrong:

dialogues.speaker: INFORMANT 2
dialogues.text: ...told me her father was the Zodiac, I'd just finished porking her, women don't lie then...

dialogues.speaker: INFORMANT 3
dialogues.text: ...found a note on my car saying "Zodiac is coming for you"...

dialogues.speaker: INFORMANT 4
dialogues.text: ..-he's on the pot - you found pot on the letters, right...

dialogues.speaker: INFORMANT 5
dialogues.text: ...-I tried telling the LAPD but they just won't listen!

dialogues.speaker: INFORMANT 6
dialogues.text: ..-he's killing geographically, cutting a big "Z" across the state. Armstrong writing - Giant Z on a notepad, and as the VOIC CONTINUE, we see OTHER PADS fill up with words like - Landlord, Radians, Binary, Witchcraft, Semaphore, and Man and TELEPHONE NUMBERS and NAMES and more numbers and more names and the voices grow and grow and grow and the word Torrance is written on a pad and finally: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 147 148 FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 98.

dialogues.speaker: INFORMANT 7, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: He said his favorite book was "The Most Dangerous Game". Armstrong looks up, interested for the first time. We're

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: July 26, 1971 - Torrance, California. Armstrong sits with DON CHENEY and SANDY PANZARELLA.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We were roommates with Leigh's brother in college and Leigh would come down sometimes. Then- Tell him about the conversation-

dialogues.speaker: CHENEY
dialogues.text: New Year's Day, 68. I go over to Leigh's house. He'd been out of work a couple months.

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: What did he do?

dialogues.speaker: CHENEY
dialogues.text: He was a teacher. Lost his job over "politics" or something. Teacher - fired? goes onto the pad below New Year's 68.

dialogues.speaker: CHENEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He was drinkin' Coors, getting a load on. Starts talking about hunting people, like that book. Says how you can put a light ona gun to use as a sight in the dark-

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: He said that?

dialogues.speaker: CHENEY
dialogues.text: Yeah. So I ask him, "How would you get away with it?" He says it'd be easy, cause there'd be no real motive to the thing. Then he says he'd write letters to the police and call himself Zodiac to mess with ‘em.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leigh liked messing with people. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: You're sure it was "Zodiac"?

dialogues.speaker: CHENEY
dialogues.text: Yeah, I thought it was a stupid name. So I told him. He gets all upset and says "I don't care what you think, I thought about it a long time, and that's the name I'm gonna use."

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: He'd been thinking about it a long time.

dialogues.speaker: CHENEY
dialogues.text: He was raw about losing his job at the school. Talked about shooting out the tires of a school bus and picking off the "little darlings".

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: He used those words?

dialogues.speaker: CHENEY
dialogues.text: That's what made me remember. Afterwards I told my wife I didn't wanna see him again and I haven't since. Other thing is, Leigh's into skindiving. I know he's been up to that lake a bunch of times, the one in Napa-

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: Berryessa. Did you ever go with him?

dialogues.speaker: CHENEY
dialogues.text: Couple times we went fishing by Putah Creek near there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell him when you put it together.

dialogues.speaker: CHENEY
dialogues.text: About a year ago in the paper, there was a story about the Zodiac, and it all comes back. I tried to call the local cops-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They blew him off. Thought he was a nut. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CHENEY
dialogues.text: So I said forget it. But then I told Sandy about it-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I made him call Manhattan Beach P.D. I got a friend there I knew would take it seriously.

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: And you're sure your conversation about Zodiac happened on the first day of 1968?

dialogues.speaker: CHENEY
dialogues.text: Couldn't have been any later cause I started a new job in LA on January 20th. I had to move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toschi and Armstrong, passing cops, walking and talking.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: Here's the problem. This guy...

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: Arthur Leigh Allen.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: This guy Allen, he just lays out his entire evil plan to a fishing buddy on New Year's Day?

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: I don't know. He's angry, he's drinking, he's been thinking about it for awhile... I can buy that.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: Why didn't Cheney come to us sooner?

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: I checked, he tried. First recorded contact with a PD about Allen was in Pomona, January 10th, 1970. He got lost in the shuffle.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: Does Cheney have anything against Allen - did Allen screw his wife or something? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 149 150 151 FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 101.

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: We'll do a full background, but I gotta tell you - I like this guy. Toschi pauses in the door to the Homicide Unit.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: Let's try and pull handwriting...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Armstrong, on the phone with NICOLAI. INTERCUT:

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: He was a public school teacher, they should still have a record of his application, right?

dialogues.speaker: NICOLAI
dialogues.text: Yeah. What school?

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: (checks notes) Valley Springs. Also, he may have been in the Navy which matches up with the boots thing.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLAI
dialogues.text: I'll see what I can get for you. You throw a heads-up to Mulanax?

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: I was about to.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLAI
dialogues.text: Have him check Vallejo banks, if Allen's got an account they should have check stubs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Armstrong, having lunch. Toschi enters and takes a seat.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: Sherwood called, he got the samples. (re: sandwich) Is that pastrami? Armstrong tears off half and hands it to him. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Check stubs are a wash, cause there's so little writing on them. The application's got more, but he says it doesn't look like Z. He's not ruling him out, but he can't rule him in either.

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: Well, that's... vague.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: (chewing) He needs more samples. Oh, also - our guy's a perv. When Mel got the application from Valley Springs, they told him Allen had been fired for touching kids.

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: Touching?

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: Polite euphemism. What do you want to do?

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: Let me make a few calls. He rises to leave. Toschi, shouting after him:

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: Can I have the rest of your-

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Yes!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Armstrong, on the phone with PANZARELLA. INTERCUT:

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: Did you and Mr. Cheney have a chance to look at the copies of the Zodiac letters we sent?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, some of that stuff is creepy.

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: We know. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I mean creepy like Leigh. He misspells words like that, thinks it's funny. And he makes up rhymes, too. Like that one "I feel it my bones, you ache to know my name"... Very Leigh.

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: What about the handwriting?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. Don't you have experts for that stuff?

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: Our man at Questioned Documents says it's inconclusive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe he did it with his other hand.

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: The letters are a little too neat for someone to have written with the wrong hand-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not for Leigh. Armstrong leans forward in his chair.

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's ambidextrous. He can write with both hands. Didn't you know that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toschi and Armstrong, sitting with Captain Lee.

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: Here's our theory - In every day life Allen uses his left hand, job applications, letters to friends, etcetera. But he writes the Zodiac letters with his right hand producing a different handwriting that he can't be linked to. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 153 154 155 FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 104.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: We gotta go see this guy, Chief.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN LEE
dialogues.text: Where is he?

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: Vallejo, he works at Union Oil in Pinole. He's also got a brother who lives up there.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN LEE
dialogues.text: See 'em both. And bring Mulanax in, it's his backyard.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: Because that worked so well in Riverside. (off Lee's look) Cooperation at all costs, that's us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: August 4, 1971 - Vallejo. Establishing. A HUGE COMPLEX. INT. UNION OIL REFINERY -- BREAK ROOM --— DAY 155 A FOREMAN leads Toschi, Armstrong, and Mulanax into the cramped meeting room.

dialogues.speaker: PINOLE FOREMAN
dialogues.text: You can talk to him in here. Coke machine's busted, by the way. Toschi looks over at the machine, out of order since 1957

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: No kidding.

dialogues.speaker: PINOLE FOREMAN
dialogues.text: I'll go get him for you. The Foreman leaves. Mulanax turns to the others.

dialogues.speaker: MULANAX
dialogues.text: How do you want to do this?

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: Bill talked to the informants. He leads, we follow? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 155 FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 105.

dialogues.speaker: MULANAX
dialogues.text: Okay by me. Armstrong nods - "fine". FOOTSTEPS in the hallway. HEAVY. The detectives turn to the closed door in anticipation. T door opens... and ARTHUR LEIGH ALLEN fills it. Over 200 l Close cropped buzzcut with graying hair. Confused. Armstrong steps forward, all business. Immediately:

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: Mr. Allen, I'm Inspector Bill Armstrong, this is Inspector David Toschi, and that's Sergeant Jack Mulanax - we're investigating the Zodiac murders in San Francisco and Vallejo. Sit, please. Allen does. Nervous.

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: An informant notified us that you made certain statements eleven months prior to the first Zodiac murder and if they're true, they're quite incriminating. Do you recall having any such conversation?

dialogues.speaker: LEIGH ALLEN
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: MULANAX
dialogues.text: Have you ever read or heard about the Zodiac? Allen, surprised the second cop has joined in.

dialogues.speaker: LEIGH ALLEN
dialogues.text: When it was first in the papers, sure. I didn't follow up after those first reports.

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: LEIGH ALLEN
dialogues.text: Because it was too morbid. I told all this to the other officer. Now it's the detectives turn to be thrown.

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: Which other officer? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LEIGH ALLEN
dialogues.text: From Vallejo. Mulanax shoots Toschi a head shake - "I don't know"

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: Do you remember the officer's name?

dialogues.speaker: LEIGH ALLEN
dialogues.text: No. But it was right after the murder at the Lake.

dialogues.speaker: MULANAX
dialogues.text: And what did you tell this officer?

dialogues.speaker: LEIGH ALLEN
dialogues.text: I told him that I'd gone to Salt Point that weekend to skin dive. I was alone but I met a couple there. I have their names at home if you want them.

dialogues.speaker: MULANAX
dialogues.text: That would be great, Arthur.

dialogues.speaker: LEIGH ALLEN
dialogues.text: Leigh.

dialogues.speaker: MULANAX
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: LEIGH ALLEN
dialogues.text: Leigh. Nobody calls me Arthur. Also, that day when I came home, my neighbor saw me. It was about four. I forgot to tell the officer about that.

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: What's your neighbor's name?

dialogues.speaker: LEIGH ALLEN
dialogues.text: Bill White. But he died about a week afterwards. Heart attack. So I never called to follow up. (suddenly) The knives I had in my car with blood on them, the blood came from a chicken I killed for dinner. The three detectives, stunned.

dialogues.speaker: MULANAX
dialogues.text: What? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LEIGH ALLEN
dialogues.text: That weekend, there were two knives in my car. Maybe Bill saw them and called the first cop on me.

dialogues.speaker: MULANAX
dialogues.text: We'll be checking on that. Let me ask you something else, were you in Southern California at any time during 1966?

dialogues.speaker: LEIGH ALLEN
dialogues.text: You mean about the Riverside killing? A beat.

dialogues.speaker: MULANAX
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: LEIGH ALLEN
dialogues.text: I guess I was down there around the same time. I used to go down a lot, I like the auto races. Armstrong looks over at Toschi, who still hasn't spoken. "Do you want to jump in?" Toschi stays quiet. Observing.

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: Our informant tells us you're ambidextrous.

dialogues.speaker: LEIGH ALLEN
dialogues.text: No. That's untrue.

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: You can't write with both hands?

dialogues.speaker: LEIGH ALLEN
dialogues.text: They tried to make me when I was little, but I couldn't. I'm left handed.

dialogues.speaker: MULANAX
dialogues.text: He also says you made statements about killing school children. Allen, becoming upset.

dialogues.speaker: LEIGH ALLEN
dialogues.text: No. That's horrible. That's a horrible thing to say... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: So you weren't angry about being fired from Valley Springs for touching your students? Allen looks up at him. Tears in his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: LEIGH ALLEN
dialogues.text: I am not the Zodiac. And if I was, I certainly wouldn't tell you. Silence... And then Toschi finally speaks:

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: That's a nice watch.

dialogues.speaker: LEIGH ALLEN
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: Can I see it? Allen holds it up for them. It's the Zodiac Watch.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Where did you get it?

dialogues.speaker: LEIGH ALLEN
dialogues.text: It was a Christmas gift from my mother two years ago.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: That's sweet. Tell me something, Arthur, do you remember anyone you might have had a conversation with regarding the Zodiac?

dialogues.speaker: LEIGH ALLEN
dialogues.text: Maybe Ted Kidder or Phil Tucker at Vallejo Recreation, but I'm not positive. I used to work there... (suddenly realizing) Ohhhh, The Most Dangerous Game!

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: LEIGH ALLEN
dialogues.text: The Most Dangerous Game! That's why you're here isn't it? Best thing I read in high school. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LEIGH ALLEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It's about this man who waits for people to get shipwrecked on his island because he's tired of hunting animals, so he hunts the people for the challenge.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: Man is the most dangerous animal?

dialogues.speaker: LEIGH ALLEN
dialogues.text: That's the whole point to the story! Great book. The WHISTLE outside the plant blows. Lunch.

dialogues.speaker: LEIGH ALLEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: May I go?

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: Yes. Thank you for your time. Allen rises to leave...

dialogues.speaker: LEIGH ALLEN
dialogues.text: I'm willing to help you in anyway possible. I can't wait until the day comes when police officers aren't referred to as "pigs".

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: Thanks. We'll be in touch. Allen exits the room. The detectives stand there.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: So... does anyone think this suspect warrants further investigation? 109. 155

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toschi, Armstrong, and Mulanax sit in the home of JOHN an CATHERINE ALLEN - Allen's brother and sister-in-law. Armstrong, laying out papers on the coffee table.

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: These are copies of the letters Zodiac sent us. Would you mind taking a look at them?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN ALLEN
dialogues.text: You think my brother's the Zodiac. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: He's someone we're looking at.

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE ALLEN
dialogues.text: Are you going to arrest him?

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: It doesn't work that way, Mrs. Allen. We don't go around arresting people because we're interested in them as suspects. Catherine begins examining the letters.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN ALLEN
dialogues.text: Leigh's always been troubled.

dialogues.speaker: MULANAX
dialogues.text: Is it true about the children?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN ALLEN
dialogues.text: Unfortunately. We don't see him much anymore. Since we found out. Toschi notes the TODDLER TOYS on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: What's your feeling about Don Cheney?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN ALLEN
dialogues.text: Don Cheney, my old roommate? Is he the one who contacted you?

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: That's confidential, sir. John considers this.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN ALLEN
dialogues.text: Don's a very reliable guy. If he were to tell you something, I'd believe it to be true. Catherine suddenly stabs a finger down at a letter.

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE ALLEN
dialogues.text: This one.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: What about it?

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE ALLEN
dialogues.text: Here, where he spells Christmas with two s's. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 156 157 FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT ll.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: They look at the Belli letter - This is the Zodiac speaki I wish you a happy Christmass...

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE ALLEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We got a Christmas card from Leigh a couple years ago. He spelled it the exact same way, "Christ-mass". Silence. John Allen looks up to the cops:

dialogues.speaker: JOHN ALLEN
dialogues.text: What can we do to help?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toschi, briefing their Captain.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: The brother's gonna search Leigh's bedroom next time he goes out of town.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN LEE
dialogues.text: Gets you around a search warrant.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: For now. If we get something, Mulanax will take it to the Vallejo DA to search the house properly. We also talked to the cop who interviewed Allen before. Doesn't remember how he got onto him but said he didn't look like a killer, so he didn't like him for Z.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN LEE
dialogues.text: But you do.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: I wish we could've taken him in right there.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN LEE
dialogues.text: Take it slow. Try and get more stuff to Sherwood, a match'll get you a lot farther with the warrants— Armstrong pokes his head in from the SQUAD ROOM:

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: Dave, you got Avery on two. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: Tell him to screw.

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: Should I communicate that verbatim or can I spice it up a bit?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Avery, asleep in his car. Parked across from Morti's. A RAPPING on the window. Avery awakes with a JOLT. GRAYSMIT Avery gets out, hungover. Begins walking to the Chronicle

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: I've been thinking-

dialogues.speaker: AVERY
dialogues.text: God save us all.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: The letter to Melvin Belli. It was sent exactly one year after the Lake Herman Road murder. And the one to Cheri Bates' father and the Riverside paper was sent exactly six months after her death. She was killed a day before Halloween, you received a Halloween card-

dialogues.speaker: AVERY
dialogues.text: All fascinating pieces of minutiae, Roberto, but it's a little early in the day-

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: It's eleven. You missed Editorial.

dialogues.speaker: AVERY
dialogues.text: Spectacular.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Graysmith and Avery exit the elevator. Passing SHORTY, wh raises his hands in mock surrender:

dialogues.speaker: SHORTY
dialogues.text: Don't shoot, Avery! Take what you want, but leave me my life! He breaks up, cackling. Avery, not breaking stride: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: AVERY
dialogues.text: Suck my nuts, Short Man.

dialogues.speaker: SHORTY
dialogues.text: (good naturedly) Fuck you and the retard!

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Why does he keep calling me that? They reach Graysmith's desk.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do you think I should call Toschi about the pattern of the letters?

dialogues.speaker: AVERY
dialogues.text: And alert his little banana republic? They're holding back. He hasn't called in weeks.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: You think they have a suspect?

dialogues.speaker: AVERY
dialogues.text: Haven't the foggiest. But do I have a surprise for him...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Armstrong walks over to Toschi's desk.

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: Hiccup with Cheney - Allen made "improper advances" toward his daughter.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: When?

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: In '67. Could give Cheney a motive against Allen.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: Okay, but why would Cheney go see him after that? If someone was messing with your daughter would you go spilt a six-pack with him?

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Armstrong, Catherine Allen on one! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 160 161 FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 114.

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: Here goes nothing... Armstrong picks up. Toschi listens in.

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Thanks for getting back to us.

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE ALLEN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I haven't been able to find the Christmas card I told you about.

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: That's okay, just keep looking.

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE ALLEN
dialogues.text: Leigh moved his trailer up to Santa Rosa this weekend for school, so John searched his bedroom at my mother's house. He didn't find any codes or knives...

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: What about something we can test for handwriting?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toschi and Armstrong, standing next to Morrill as he chec the handwriting exemplars for Allen. This time, Toschi is silent. Morrill lowers the magnifying glass and sighs.

dialogues.speaker: MORRILL
dialogues.text: This suspect is not your Zodiac.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: Did these samples match his checks stubs and application?

dialogues.speaker: MORRILL
dialogues.text: Perfectly.

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: Then we just retested his left hand! We already know he's ambidextrous-—

dialogues.speaker: MORRILL
dialogues.text: In my thirty-eight years of experience, I've never seen anyone that ambidextrous. Both hands would have commonalities. I'm sorry, but this just won't work.  FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 115.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toschi scoops up his ringing phone. INTERCUT:

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: Homicide, Toschi.

dialogues.speaker: MULANAX
dialogues.text: Dave, Jack Mulanax. We struck out with the judge. He won't sign off on a warrant for Allen's house.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: MULANAX
dialogues.text: He said it's not enough. Unless we bring him a handwriting match or some evidence-

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: How are we gonna get evidence if we can't even toss his house?

dialogues.speaker: MULANAX
dialogues.text: I don't know. I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toschi and Armstrong with Captain Lee.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN LEE
dialogues.text: What do you want to do?
