dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: Don't know what we can do without Vallejo. We need Allen's other hand, and we can't get it without a warrant.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN LEE
dialogues.text: Are there other guys you should be looking at? Toschi and Armstrong exchange a look.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: About twenty-three hundred. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN LEE
dialogues.text: Okay then. A beat. They turn and leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Avery. Circles under his eyes. Underweight. Lounging on a couch across from Peck.

dialogues.speaker: PECK
dialogues.text: You can't go on like this.

dialogues.speaker: AVERY
dialogues.text: Like what? Happy and horny? He lights a smoke and grins. Peck holds up a LETTER.

dialogues.speaker: PECK
dialogues.text: You wrote the Department of Justice and asked to be put in charge of the Zodiac investigation?

dialogues.speaker: AVERY
dialogues.text: I merely suggested that those with intimate knowledge of the case create an information clearing house to promote an exchange and freeflow of ideas.

dialogues.speaker: PECK
dialogues.text: And that you run it.

dialogues.speaker: AVERY
dialogues.text: Who better than me? The "marked man". Peck leans forward, unamused. Avery rises.

dialogues.speaker: PECK
dialogues.text: If you want to work here I need three things - One, stop boozing - two, stop whatever else you're doing - and three, cut this kind of nonsense out. Unsteady on his feet. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: AVERY
dialogues.text: Dear Templeton, if at any time you feel my excellent work isn't in step with your piece of shit rag, I'll more than happily decamp for greener pastures. He exits through the door. Peck shouting after him:

dialogues.speaker: PECK
dialogues.text: I mean it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Graysmith at his desk. He looks up at Peck's shout to see Avery wobbling towards him.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: What was that about?

dialogues.speaker: AVERY
dialogues.text: A little editorial tete-a-tete. Let's get a drink.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: It's ten in the morning.

dialogues.speaker: AVERY
dialogues.text: An early lunch.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Are you okay? Avery stares at him for a moment. Touched.

dialogues.speaker: AVERY
dialogues.text: Not at all. But thank you for asking. Avery claps him on the back.

dialogues.speaker: AVERY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hey, Shorty, wanna get a drink?

dialogues.speaker: SHORTY
dialogues.text: Fuck, yeah! They head for the elevators. Hyman, passing by.

dialogues.speaker: HYMAN
dialogues.text: Paul, where are you going? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As it FINISHES CONSTRUCTION.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Avery merely raises his arm, SHOOTING HIM THE FINGER. turning around. Graysmith. Watching him until the doors close. So how do you want to start doing this? 118. 166 Not He gets in the elevator with Shorty. On

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: We need to recheck Benson and Flowers-

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN LEE
dialogues.text: Why does Napa keep calling about a Rick Marshall?

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: I'm iffy on Marshall, but Vallejo's on Benson and Flowers...

dialogues.speaker: MULANAX, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I looked at Benson and Flowers, they're morons, but they're not Z-

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Narlow hasn't gotten Marshall's prints yet-

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: So it's not Benson or Flowers?

dialogues.speaker: MULANAX, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: No ballistics match-

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Sherwood says he's a no- Covering A YEAR. Over this:

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: What about the watermarks-—

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: What about the postmarks?

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN LEE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Every letter except the last one is postmarked San Francisco-

dialogues.speaker: MORRILL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: There's an Eaton Watermark on the first three letters, but then it changes to a "Fifth Avenue" watermark which is sold at Woolworths-

dialogues.speaker: PAROLE OFFICER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: This parolee David Carpenter hasn't checked in, I think he looks pretty good as your guy-

dialogues.speaker: NARLOW, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I really like him for it-

dialogues.speaker: NARLOW, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: No way it's him.

dialogues.speaker: MORRILL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: It's not his handwriting- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Big fat no on Marshall- Carpenter was in custody at the time-

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: It's a dead end, Chief- We've got nothing. SILENCE. The Pyramid - FINISHED. Then:

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE ALLEN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: It's been awhile since we've heard from you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Armstrong sits across from Catherine Allen.

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: We have a lot of cases, Mrs. Allen and a lot of suspects on this case-

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE ALLEN
dialogues.text: You've moved off my brother-in- law.

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: We couldn't get the warrant.

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE ALLEN
dialogues.text: Last year we arranged to get Leigh help from a social worker. He only went twice. We saw him recently. The first time in nine months, his mother brought him by to see the new baby- After he came by, I went to that social worker. He couldn't talk about a former patient. I told him he was a Zodiac suspect and just asked him straight if he thought Leigh was capable of killing people-

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: But because of patient confidentiality-

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE ALLEN
dialogues.text: The man said yes. Armstrong stares at her. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: Why hadn't you seen him in nine months?

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE ALLEN
dialogues.text: He's going to school in Santa Rosa.

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: Santa Rosa? Where's he living?

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE ALLEN
dialogues.text: In his trailer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toschi looks up as Armstrong enters.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: We gotta go check a Z tip on Mare Island-

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: The trailer in Santa Rosa.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: Leigh Allen. The one he lives out of while he goes to school. Toschi leans back, his attention captured.

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You're Z. You've taken trophies - a wallet, keys, bloody shirt. Are you gonna hide them in your mother's house or in your own trailer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toschi and Armstrong, walking with Captain Lee.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN LEE
dialogues.text: It's in Santa Rosa?

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: Sonoma County. We wouldn't have to go through the Vallejo D.A. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN LEE
dialogues.text: It's been eleven months since you talked to this guy, now you want to search his trailer?

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: If we find something, great, if not, at least we get his prints and handwriting from both hands. Turning a corner:

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN LEE
dialogues.text: I thought Sherwood shut you down.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: What if we could get a second opinion?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toschi with handwriting expert TERRY PASCOE.

dialogues.speaker: PASCOE
dialogues.text: I don't want to step on Sherwood's toes, he trained me at this-—

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: Terry, all we need to know is - if the suspect is ambidextrous, could he have written the letters with his other hand?

dialogues.speaker: PASCOE
dialogues.text: Off the record? There are differing schools of thought on this. Get samples from his other hand. If he's the Zodiac, you'll get a match.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Captain Lee sits on the edge of Toschi's desk facing the detectives.

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: ...we got that from Pascoe, meanwhile I spoke to a psychologist who'd be willing to testify that someone who undergoes a personality change like Zodiac would manifest it physically, altering his handwriting- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: Which is why Sherwood didn't get a match from Allen's samples. We've got Pascoe and this psychologist, coupled with Cheney it could be enough for the warrant. Lee rises, heading for the door.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN LEE
dialogues.text: Get Cheney on the record.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DON CHENEY listens as Armstrong rapidly READS OFF a LIST

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: ...that on January 1st 1968, Arthur Allen told you about hunting people, that he said he would attach a light to a gun and shoot people in lovers' lane areas and would write letters to confuse the police, that he would shoot the tires off a school bus and shoot the kiddies as they came bouncing out, and that he would call himself Zodiac.

dialogues.speaker: CHENEY
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: And you'd be willing to swear to this under oath in Superior Court?

dialogues.speaker: CHENEY
dialogues.text: Without any hesitation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toschi, Armstrong and Captain Lee stand around a SPEAKER PHONE. On the other end is Santa Rosa D.A. JOHN HAWKES.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN LEE
dialogues.text: John, I got Dave Toschi and Bill Armstrong with me and we think they've got enough for a warrant. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN LEE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: They're going to take you through this. I'm assuming you've got Mr. Cheney's statements?

dialogues.speaker: SANTA ROSA D.A., (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (through phone) Yup.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN LEE
dialogues.text: Okay. Guys? Armstrong opens his notes.

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: Suspect is Arthur Leigh Allen, current residence, Sunset Trailer Court, Santa Rosa, California. Physical description - Allen is similar in height, weight, and build to a man seen at Lake Berryessa the day of the stabbings. SANTA ROSA D.A. I understand he doesn't look much like the San Francisco composite.

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: True his height and weight are sketchy, but lumbering Caucasian with crewcut is right on-

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: (breaking in) We never had much confidence in the composite from the kids - even the patrolman who saw Zodiac said he didn't look much like that sketch.

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: Military bootprints - Allen was a Navy man and wears size 10 1/2, the same size found at Berryessa-

dialogues.speaker: SANTA ROSA D.A., (0.S.)
dialogues.text: What about guns?

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: Cheney says Allen owns several firearms. We'll list them all in the warrant.

dialogues.speaker: SANTA ROSA D.A., (0.S.)
dialogues.text: And the ciphers? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: Could be code training in the Navy, and people have seen Allen with ciphers in the past.

dialogues.speaker: SANTA ROSA D.A., (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Really, who?

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: His sister in law, and a guy named Phil Tucker who he worked with at a public pool.

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: Tucker also told us he had a conversation with Allen about how to attach a flashlight to the barrel of a gun.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN LEE
dialogues.text: John, that's two sources on the ciphers and two on the flashlight.

dialogues.speaker: SANTA ROSA D.A., (0.S.)
dialogues.text: What about his threats on children?

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN LEE
dialogues.text: Suspect worked at elementary schools and was fired for molestation in March/April '68 - could give him motive.

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: At the very least, it's home turf; he'd have knowledge of bus routes, which both threats centered around.

dialogues.speaker: SANTA ROSA D.A., (0.S.)
dialogues.text: What about the bomb?

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: Allen works as a chemist, which means he knows the compounds needed to create explosives.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN LEE
dialogues.text: Take him through the geography.

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: Vallejo murders - Allen lives in Vallejo with his mother in her basement. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Berryessa murder - The day the kids were stabbed, Allen's neighbor saw bloody knives in his truck which he claimed was used to kill a chicken.

dialogues.speaker: SANTA ROSA D.A., (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Does he have any alibis?

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: He claimed he did, but has been unable to produce the names of a “couple" he supposedly met on the day of Berryessa-

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: Bottom line is, Allen can't alibi up on anything - Riverside, Vallejo, the Lake, or us. Now tell him about the name.

dialogues.speaker: SANTA ROSA D.A., (0.S.)
dialogues.text: What name?

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: "Zodiac". Allen wears a watch that bears both the word and the crosshair symbol. And he mentioned Zodiac to Cheney a year and a half before it appeared in any letter. They stare at the phone, awaiting the response. Finally:

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN LEE
dialogues.text: John?

dialogues.speaker: SANTA ROSA D.A., (0.S.)
dialogues.text: That's pretty good, guys.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN LEE
dialogues.text: We think so too.

dialogues.speaker: SANTA ROSA D.A., (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Let's take it to a judge...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: September 14, 1972. Toschi and Armstrong get out of their along with Santa Rosa D.A. INVESTIGATOR CAMERON and Santa Rosa DETECTIVE ROY. The four men walk in silence. Reachin the trailer. Toschi turns to Armstrong. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 170 171 FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 126.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: You ready? Armstrong nods. Toschi turns and KNOCKS on the DOOR... It swings open on it's own. Unlocked.

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE ROY
dialogues.text: Mr. Allen, this is the Santa Rosa Police Department! We have a warrant to search your residence! No response. Toschi shrugs and steps inside...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dank. Blinds drawn. Nobody home.

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE ROY
dialogues.text: I'll check with the neighbors. He ducks out. Stacks of books and clothes in every corner A chattering sound and an animal smell. Rank. Like shit. Toschi wrinkles his nose. Then he sees - Caged squirrels. Stacked on top of the books. Some run around the trailer free. Toschi tries to step over them. Cracks a window for the smell. Roy returns.

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE ROY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Neighbor said he tore out of here about a half hour ago. You think somebody tipped him?

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: Doesn't matter, we're not leaving till he comes back. Shall we? They begin poking around.

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: (to Cameron and Roy) Help me with the bed? They grab hold of the bed. Moving it to reveal - A WOODEN DILDO. A HUGE JAR OF PETROLEUM JELLY. Toschi, in the kitchenette. Checking the fridge. Spotty with food. Opens the icebox-

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: Jesus!

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: What? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 171 172 FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 127.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: Squirrel. Armstrong, not understanding. He comes to look - there is FROZEN SQUIRREL in the icebox.

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE ROY
dialogues.text: Piece of work, this guy. Armstrong nods. Moves to check the drawers in the living room. Toschi, searching the closet.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: Two blue windbreakers.

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE ROY
dialogues.text: Like at the Stine scene?

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: (rooting around) Yup, but no blood - hey, hey black gloves. Size seven, same as we found in the cab. He's got the same shoe size and glove size as Z - I'm sure it's just a coincidence- Armstrong, checking the drawers. One, two three- He STOPS

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: Dave, I got a gun. Check that - two guns. Both .22's. One automatic, one revolver-

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: That's interesting, because he's got an M-1 rifle in his closet. Armstrong goes to look. A .30 cal carbine. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: For little darlings who come bouncing off buses? Toschi smiles. The sound of a CAR OUTSIDE...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur Leigh Allen, pulling up in WHITE KHARMANN GHIA - IDENTICAL to Bryan Hartnell's. Allen gets out. Lumbering. Slows when he sees the detectives.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: Hi, Arthur. Remember us?  FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 128.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toschi and Armstrong sit in chairs, waiting for the resul Nervous. Through the glass to Lee's office we see the Captain talking on the phone. Hangs up. Opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN LEE
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: On the handwriting?

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN LEE
dialogues.text: Ballistics - no match, prints - no match, writing - no match.

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: On both hands, right, we got writing from both of his hands-—

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN LEE
dialogues.text: And neither hand matches.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: Tell Sherwood to try again-

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN LEE
dialogues.text: Fellas. He's not your guy. Silence as this sinks in. Toschi stands and leaves, SLAMM THE DOOR. Lee heads after him, leaving Armstrong sitting there, equally devastated that they were wrong...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toschi stalks outside, fuming. Lee emerges behind him.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN LEE
dialogues.text: What do you want? Time off? A hug? Toschi turns.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: You know what the worst part is? I can't tell if I wanted it to be Allen so bad because I thought it was him, or because I wanted all of this to be over... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN LEE
dialogues.text: Because you thought it was him. And I did too. (pause) Maybe you should take some vacation. Spend some time with the wife and kids. Go to Candlestick.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN LEE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Take in a movie.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: 175A ON A GIANT MOVIE SCREEN - JOHN VERNON (THE MAYOR) re KILLER'S LETTER that's projected on a screen in his offic 176

dialogues.speaker: JOHN VERNON, (THE MAYOR)
dialogues.text: To the city of San Francisco - I will enjoy killing one person everyday until you pay me one hundred thousand dollars...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hundreds of San Francisco's elite sit in their finery watching a police screening of Dirty Harry unspool in fro Among them, Toschi and his wife. of them.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN VERNON, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: If you agree, say so tomorrow morning in the personal column, San Francisco Chronicle and I will set up a meeting... ON THE MOVIE SCREEN - the shot is now a close-up of the letter (which looks very Zodiacish):

dialogues.speaker: JOHN VERNON
dialogues.text: If I do not hear from you, it will be my next pleasure to kill a Catholic Priest or a... Vernon pauses in distaste - the word is "nigger". CUT TO Close on Vernon as he reads the killer's signature:

dialogues.speaker: JOHN VERNON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Scorpio. IN THE AUDIENCE - On Toschi's face. Watching. Numb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Late in the movie - Toschi, almost at the end of his rope (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SCORPIO KILLER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I've got seven kids from the Fourth Street School, now listen, I've got the bus- ONSCREEN - SCORPIO is holding a WOMAN BUS DRIVER HOSTAGE front of a YELLOW SCHOOL BUS filled with KIDS. (note - from here till the end of the written dialogue Cl Eastwood does not appear onscreen - in other words CLINT EASTWOOD WILL NOT APPEAR IN THIS MOVIE). A LITTLE GIRL tr to get off the bus, interrupting his ransom call:

dialogues.speaker: SCORPIO KILLER
dialogues.text: -come on now, honey, that's a good girl, back in the bus... (she goes - into phone) And I've got the bus driver. Here she is, just tell him. IN THE AUDIENCE - Toschi leans over, whispering to his wi

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: You want some popcorn?

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI'S WIFE
dialogues.text: Do you want me to come with you? He shakes his head. Rises and heads for the exit, scootin past other audience members, enraptured by the movie. Onl one other person in the theater notices Toschi go- GRAYSMITH. Sitting with MELANIE. He watches Toschi leave.

dialogues.speaker: BUS DRIVER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: It wasn't my fault, he had as gun-

dialogues.speaker: SCORPIO KILLER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Just tell him your name...  178 FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 130.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toschi stands alone under a banner Dirty Harry. Trying to light a smoke in the wind.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: The good guy shoots him in the chest. That's how it ends. Toschi turns to see Graysmith. He looks shaken by the who thing. Our two heroes, standing there. Meeting for the first time. Toschi stares at him.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: I know you.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: I work at the Chronicle. Robert Graysmith - maybe Paul Avery's mentioned me?

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: No, that's not it... They shake hands, Graysmith masking his disappointment.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Dave Toschi, nice to meet you. Behind them, the THEATER DOORS OPEN. The invigorated audience pours out, headed for the afterparty. The POLICE COMMISSIONER, passes by, in high spirits.

dialogues.speaker: POLICE COMMISSIONER
dialogues.text: Dave! That Harry Callahan did a hell of a job closing your case, huh?

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: Sure did, Commissioner. Good thing he didn't let due process get in the way, huh? The Commissioner gives him a funny look but chuckles anyw and moves on. Toschi looks back to Graysmith. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 178 179 FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 131.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So what do you do over at the paper?

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: I'm a cartoonist.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: That's good. That's a good job. Make people laugh. His wife appears, taking his arm. Ready to leave.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Nice meeting you. He turns to leave when

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: You're gonna catch him. You're Dave Toschi. Toschi turns back. Smiles and shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: Pal? They're already making movies about it. Graysmith doesn't know what to say. Toschi heads off. We hold on Graysmith, standing on that cold street corner as

dialogues.speaker: BLACKNESS. 179
dialogues.text: Is it over? Then, - faint music. Of the times. The mid 70's. And news reports. Something about... Watergate? Bobby Fischer? Saigon? Squeaky Fromme? And there's rock and roll and fun and the beginnings of disco and Patty Hearst and Zebra Murders and "Son of Sam" and it builds and builds until..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A BABY GIRL - lifted to her parent's shoulder... And it's GRAYSMITH. Older. Hair closer cropped. An expert at this. He bounces his daughter MARGOT who coos.

dialogues.speaker: NEWSCASTER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: -.-has confirmed that columnist Jimmy Breslin of the New York Daily News has received a letter penned by the Son of Sam. Dubbed the .44 Caliber Killer by the press and later "Son of Sam" by himself, the killer began his rampage in 1976, targeting couples in parked cars, and communicating with authorities through a series of handwritten letters. Interest piqued, Graysmith heads to the LIVING ROOM. More feminine now that a wife lives here. It's late, everyone else asleep.

dialogues.speaker: NEWSCASTER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: If any of this sounds familiar to our viewers, it's because our own fair city once had a very similar brush with the macabre. In light of the events in New York, tonight, we look back on what police call "A Cold Case", possibly the most famous in history - The Zodiac. Graysmith sits. Intrigued. FOOTAGE of Zodiac Letters.

dialogues.speaker: NEWSCASTER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Shortly after a connection was established between an unsolved 1966 murder in Riverside and the Cipher Slayer, Zodiac's letters became more infrequent, and finally nil. Many believe he is dead. But Inspector David Toschi has different ideas. File footage of TOSCHI. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: NEWSCASTER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Toschi, who rose to public prominence for his investigations into both the Zodiac and the Zebra Murders, is currently making headlines as the next possible Chief of Police. Along with his partner William Armstrong, Toschi is the only San Francisco detective still working a case that at one time commanded the attention of hundreds of policemen. Now it's down to just two. And the killer, still at large, who haunts them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toschi and Armstrong pull up to a curb by Armstrong's apartment building. Done for the day. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: 180A CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Armstrong begins gathering up his stuff. Preoccupied with something. Maybe even upset. Toschi notices.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: You want to keep the car tonight?

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: It's your turn.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: I know, but if you drop me at my place, you can have it. Armstrong looks out the window - his WIFE stands in the d to the building, waiting. Toschi sees her too. Strange. Armstrong turns back to Toschi. Has to tell him.

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: You should keep the car.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: I'm not coming in tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: What's up?

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: I'm done. I put in for a transfer.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: Where?

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: I'm looking at fraud. I can't be on call anymore.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: I understand.

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: Rather watch my kids grow up, you know?

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: Yeah. Hey, good for you.

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: You'll be okay? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: I'll be fine. Armstrong smiles. Gets out of the car. Thinks of somethin

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: Hey... I'm not leaving you holding the bag on anything, am I? He means Zodiac. Toschi knows it.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: Nope.

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: Hey, now you got time to get that sushi. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: 180B
dialogues.text: 181 182 183 184 Armstrong smiles. Walks to his building. Toschi sees him to his wife. He waves. She waves back, knowing what just transpired. He watches the Armstrongs disappear inside. Then drives away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The NEWS ROOM. Different. Old faces gone. New faces there A YOUNG REPORTER setting up shop at what used to be Avery Desk. Graysmith watches. Finally walks over.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Hi. Robert Graysmith.

dialogues.speaker: JENNINGS
dialogues.text: (absently) Duffy Jennings. Graysmith watches him get comfortable in Avery's chair.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: The guy who used to sit there was a great reporter.

dialogues.speaker: JENNINGS
dialogues.text: I'm sure he was. I mean, it's an honor to leave the Chronicle and go work for the Sacramento Bee. He threads a piece of paper into his typewriter.

dialogues.speaker: JENNINGS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Nice meeting you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: October 11, 1977. The eighth anniversary of Stine's death Toschi sits in his car like always. Except this time, the passenger seat is empty. He's alone. Toschi sighs and put the car in gear. Driving away. We HOLD on the corner... Until a YELLOW CAB pulls up to it. The Passenger gets out and pays the driver. GRAYSMITH. Taking in the scene for t first time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Graysmith, sitting on his couch, going through yellowed newspaper clippings from Zodiac. Turning page after page. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 185 186 FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 135.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The headlines flitting past - "'I've Killed Seven' Zodiac Claims", "Zodiac Sends New Letter Says He's Killed Ten", Zodiac Letter Claims 17+", "Cops No Closer On Zodiac's Identity"- A VOICE BY HIS EAR:

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: "I am not Paul Avery." Graysmith starts. Melanie laughs.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The boys need tuck-ins and the poop machine needs changing.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Flip you for it?

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: You wish. (looking at the book) No one has more Zodiac crap than you. Graysmith blinks at this. Looking down at the album. The same name at the top of every article - By Paul Avery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Graysmith walks down the dock among houseboats. Comes to in particular - with SHEET METAL over the windows. He kno on the door. COUGHING from inside. It cracks a little to reveal AVERY. Face gaunt. Eyes bloodshot. Looks like hell. Taking in Graysmith. Then:

dialogues.speaker: AVERY
dialogues.text: You gotta be fucking kidding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Avery leads Graysmith inside, clearing away some of the m Graysmith, a little surprised at the state of things.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: I hope I'm not interrupting anything... It's clear from his surroundings the only thing Graysmith interrupted is Avery playing PONG. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 186 FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 136.

dialogues.speaker: AVERY
dialogues.text: Not at all. (re: Pong) Have you seen this thing? It's mesmerizing...

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Yeah. Yeah. So... how have you been?

dialogues.speaker: AVERY
dialogues.text: Can't complain. Bee's not exactly the Chron, but fuck it, right? Work is work. You want a drink? He begins making a mixture of gin and ice.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Don't worry about it-

dialogues.speaker: AVERY
dialogues.text: No worry at all, my friend. Nobody comes by from the old days - what we got ourselves here is an occasion. (raising the bottle) To your health. And mine. Mostly mine. He raises his bottle in toast. Graysmith raises his glass Notices it's filthy. Avery drinks deeply. Graysmith does not. Putting the glass down.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: It's good to see you, Paul. Avery smiles at him and settles into a chair.

dialogues.speaker: AVERY
dialogues.text: So, what's new? He takes a seat. Graysmith takes a deep breath.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: I've been thinking.

dialogues.speaker: AVERY
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Somebody should write a book. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: AVERY
dialogues.text: "Somebody" should write a book about what?

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: About Zodiac.

dialogues.speaker: AVERY
dialogues.text: That's not new. Is that why you're here?

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: (pitching him) Nobody knows more about the case than you. You have the files - if you put together all the information, it could jog something loose-

dialogues.speaker: AVERY
dialogues.text: Lost the files.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: (horrified) You lost them?

dialogues.speaker: AVERY
dialogues.text: Lost them or tossed them, who cares, man?

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: But you wanted to be in charge of the investigation!

dialogues.speaker: AVERY
dialogues.text: That was a long time ago. (refilling his glass) We work in the daily business as in to-day. What did you think we were doing back then? You didn't really think it was important? (off his look; laughing) Oh, Jesus... We were just trying to sell newspapers. More people die in three months on the East Bay commute than that idiot killed. He offed a few citizens, wrote a few letters, and faded into footnote. What, Gray, did you think I was just sitting here waiting for you to drop by and reinvigorate my sense of purpose? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 187 188 FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 138.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Silence. Graysmith rises stiffly, suddenly formal:

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Thank you for your time. He heads for the door. As he goes:

dialogues.speaker: AVERY
dialogues.text: It's been four years, Bobby - let it go. He turns back to face Avery.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: I don't care what you say. It was important. It was important.

dialogues.speaker: AVERY
dialogues.text: Well, what the fuck did you ever do about it?

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: What-

dialogues.speaker: AVERY
dialogues.text: If it was so important, what did you do? Hovered over my desk? Stole shit out of wastebaskets? Oh, I'm sorry, I'm being unkind. You went to the library. This hits hard. Avery may be mad, but he's right. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Sorry to have bothered you. He turns and goes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Graysmith gets into his car. It's begun to rain. He sits behind the wheel. Breathing hard. Taking it all in. He comes to a decision. Puts the car in gear and drives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Late. Graysmith comes in from the rain. STACKS OF BOOKS under his arm. Melanie, watching TV. Looks up as he enter

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: Where have you been? He disappears into the bathroom. We hear water running. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: The library.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toschi at his desk. He looks up to see Graysmith.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: (no idea who this is) Hi. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: We met at the movies once.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: It must have been magical.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: I'm Robert Graysmith, I work at the Chronicle. I was wondering if I could buy you lunch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Graysmith and Toschi sit across from each other. Toschi chows down on a burger. Graysmith ignores his food. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: So you're a friend of Paul Avery's?

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: He's the reason I'm here. I wanted to ask to you about Zodiac.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: I appreciate the interest but we don't discuss open cases-—

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: What's happening with it really? Day to day?

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: We're actively pursuing all leads-

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: It's just you now, isn't it.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: Mr. Graysmith, Zodiac hasn't written in three years. Do you know how many murders San Francisco has had since then?

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: Over two hundred. That's a lot of dead people and grieving families who need our help.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: So nobody cares anymore? Toschi puts down his burger.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: Hey. JI care.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Can I show you something? Toschi shrugs. Graysmith pulls a stack of books from his briefcase and lays them on the table.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I've been doing research on the first code. Everything an amateur would need to create it can be found in these books. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So I started thinking, if you can track the books, maybe you can find the man. He hands Toschi a LIST.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I know you thought Zodiac was military so I went to every base library and got a list of people who checked out the books. That's when I found this. He points to the PRESIDIO LIBRARY LIST. Almost the entire column of books have the word "MISSING" written by them.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: "Missing"?

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: That means the book was stolen.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: Almost every book on ciphers was stolen from the Presidio Library?

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: And the Oakland Army Terminal Library. Someone didn't want to leave a record of checking them out, so he stole them. Toschi stares at him.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: Who are you again?

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: I just want to help. A beat. Toschi, mulling this over. Finally:

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: I can't allow you to help. I can't have more meetings with you to discuss what you might uncover and I certainly can't tell you to go talk to Ken Narlow in Napa, N-A- R-L-O-W in Napa who was in charge of the case up there. You understand?  FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 141.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Graysmith, seated across from Narlow.

dialogues.speaker: NARLOW
dialogues.text: I'm sorry Mr. Graysmith, but we don't cooperate with writers-

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: I'm not a writer, I'm a cartoonist. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: NARLOW
dialogues.text: And Dave Toschi sent you?

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: NARLOW
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Maybe he thought I could do some good.

dialogues.speaker: NARLOW
dialogues.text: (laughing) What are you, a boy scout?

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Eagle Scout actually. First class. A beat. Narlow, realizing he's not kidding.

dialogues.speaker: NARLOW
dialogues.text: You really want to do this, you shouldn't let me stop you. Try Vallejo. Jack Mulanax.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Graysmith, seated across from Mulanax.

dialogues.speaker: MULANAX
dialogues.text: I understand what you're trying to do, but-

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: I'm a friend of Dave Toschi's. He said you could help. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 192 193 194 FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 142.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Mulanax stares at him, silent.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The case is dead, right? Zodiac's long gone, yesterday's news?

dialogues.speaker: MULANAX
dialogues.text: That's what they say.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: So what's the harm?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mulanax leads Graysmith past ROWS OF CARDBOARD BOXES.

dialogues.speaker: MULANAX
dialogues.text: No pens, no paper, no copiers. Anything you see that's relevant, you gotta remember in your head. They turn a corner to find THREE ENORMOUS BOOKCASE TYPE SHELVES filled with boxes.

dialogues.speaker: MULANAX, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Here you go.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Which one?

dialogues.speaker: MULANAX
dialogues.text: All of them. There are more in the next room. They're all marked with these numbers. He points to one box, marked #243-146.

dialogues.speaker: MULANAX, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'll be outside. He goes. Graysmith wastes no time. Opening the top box, scanning the Vallejo police reports. Words flashing by - Ferrin, Lynch, Mageau, Corvair, Breathing phone calls, NM handwriting, painting party, hypnosis, Husted...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mulanax getting coffee as Graysmith HURRIES PAST.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Thank you very much! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He's gone before Mulanax can respond. Officer GEORGE BAWA wanders in to see this stranger's hasty departure.

dialogues.speaker: MULANAX
dialogues.text: Hey, George.

dialogues.speaker: BAWART
dialogues.text: Hey. Who was that?

dialogues.speaker: MULANAX
dialogues.text: Graysmith. Some cartoonist, thinks he's gonna solve the Zodiac. Bawart watches Graysmith running across the street toward restaurant like a madman.

dialogues.speaker: BAWART
dialogues.text: Good for him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Graysmith sits at a table scribbling furiously into a notebook. Transcribing from memory what he's just read...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Parked under a BRIDGE. Graysmith sits with Margot on his lap. The door opens. Toschi slides in, eating a hot dog.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Thanks for meeting me, Inspector.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: We're not meeting. I gotta be back in five minutes-

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Did anyone ever show Mike Mageau suspect photos?

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: He's the only surviving victim who saw Zodiac without a mask. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toschi stares

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: No, why are you asking me? Darlene and Mageau are Vallejo's investigation, Paul Stine is mine, you got four minutes now-

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Darlene Ferrin was being followed. at him.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I know Mulanax says they already found this guy, a George Waters. But he also says Darlene had lots of "admirers" who would come by the restaurant where she worked. When Darlene and her husband moved into their new house, they threw a painting party-

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: What's a painting party?

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: It's a party where people come over and help you paint.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: That sounds like a terrible party.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: But someone who was not Waters showed up that night and Darlene was really scared of him. Toschi, considering.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: You think Zodiac knew Darlene.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: And if Zodiac knew her, maybe Mageau knew Zodiac.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: We'll never know. Mageau's gone. In the wind. If you want to connect Zodiac to Darlene, you're gonna have to find another way. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: I have another way. Phone calls. The night of Darlene's murder-

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: Yeah, Zodiac called the police.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: But there were four other calls. Two to Darlene's house, one to her brother-in-law, and one to her father-in-law, just heavy breathing. They started around 1:30 a.m., before anyone in the family knew Darlene had been shot-

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: This was in the Vallejo files? Graysmith nods.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Goddammit... Margot begins to whine. Graysmith extracts a bottle from bag and starts feeding her as he continues.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Inspector, somebody doesn't just randomly prank call a victim's entire family ninety minutes after a shooting. Either Zodiac shot a random couple and then recognized Darlene- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: -or he killed Darlene on purpose.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Either way, Zodiac had to have known her. Toschi, mulling this over.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: That's good, Robert.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: I need to find Darlene's sister. Maybe she can tell me who the mystery man is.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: Try that. I gotta get back. Bye, cutie. He pats Margot's head and gets out of the car. About to leave when something occurs to him. lLeans in the window.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It is interesting you mention Zodiac calling people at home. I heard he did that in San Francisco once.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Who did he call?

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: That's privileged information and as lead on the case, I really can't tell you. (musing) But maybe Melvin Belli could.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Graysmith sits in the parlor, waiting for the famous lawy His HOUSEKEEPER sets a tray of cookies in front of him.

dialogues.speaker: HOUSEKEEPER
dialogues.text: He should be along soon. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Oh, it's fine. I've only been here- (checks his watch) Oh, wow. Two hours.

dialogues.speaker: HOUSEKEEPER
dialogues.text: He is not usually this late-

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: No, really, it's fine. These look like very good cookies. He tries one while she watches. He smiles, showing how go they are. Makes an "mmm" sound. She's satisfied.

dialogues.speaker: HOUSEKEEPER
dialogues.text: You are here about a case?

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: I'm writing a book about the Zodiac.

dialogues.speaker: HOUSEKEEPER
dialogues.text: Oh, I remember that. I spoke to him.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: You mean to Mr. Belli about the case?

dialogues.speaker: HOUSEKEEPER
dialogues.text: No. To the Zodiac when he called. He said he had to kill because it was his birthday. Graysmith puts down the cookie.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: He said it was his birthday?

dialogues.speaker: HOUSEKEEPER
dialogues.text: Yes. You want more cookies?

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: When did he call?

dialogues.speaker: HOUSEKEEPER
dialogues.text: So many years ago... Mr. Belli was away for Christmas. Gone for a week. The Zodiac called, wanted to talk to him. I said he is not here. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HOUSEKEEPER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He said "I have to kill, today is my birthday" then he hangs up. Then the letter arrives.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: So - he called before the letter arrived on- on- (checking his notes) December 20th. But Mr. Belli was only gone a week-

dialogues.speaker: HOUSEKEEPER
dialogues.text: He came back on Christmas. Not a good day to work-

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: So he left on the eighteenth.

dialogues.speaker: HOUSEKEEPER
dialogues.text: (smiling) Is that helpful?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Graysmith, on the phone with Toschi.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: She says it was his birthday!

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: You'll need to confirm that, won't you?

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: How?

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: I never spoke to her, but maybe my partner did-

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: How do I get in touch with him?

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: Don't. Bill wanted out of this as far as I'm concerned.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: So how do I confirm it?

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: If my partner spoke to someone at Justice about it, they would have put it in a report. Standard procedure.  FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 149.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Graysmith, sitting across a desk from MEL NICOLAI.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: I just need to confirm the date.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLAI
dialogues.text: Mr. Graysmith-

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: I've narrowed it down to between the 18th and the 20th of December-

dialogues.speaker: NICOLAI
dialogues.text: Okay, I'll play. Let's say this call did take place. And let's say it really was Zodiac. Why would he volunteer the day he was born? Plus, nobody died on December 18th. Just like nobody died over the weekend when he was going to kill a dozen people, or when he threatened to shoot school kids and blow up buses. He's a liar, Mr. Graysmith.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: But if it was him and he wasn't lying-

dialogues.speaker: NICOLAI
dialogues.text: Do you know how many qualifiers you just put in that sentence? (before he responds) Look, off the record - Bill Armstrong checked this out. We took it seriously. But none of our suspects at the time had the same birthday as this phantom caller. Silence. Graysmith flips his notepad shut.

dialogues.speaker: NICOLAI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Can I give you a piece of advice? You're looking in the wrong place. Handwriting and fingerprints, that's what this whole thing is about.  FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 150.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Melanie sits, staring at a newspaper article. The door op and Graysmith enters. Hanging up his coat:

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Hey, how was your day?

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: Long. Who's Sherwood Morrill?

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: He's a handwriting expert in Sacramento.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: He called, he says he can meet you tomorrow morning at 7.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Great.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: So you're taking off work?

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Just in the morning-

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: Sacramento's two hours away.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: Yes. What's this? She holds out the newspaper to him.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Oh, the article came out! Yeah, a reporter called me.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: It talks about you researching Zodiac.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Well, yeah, that's why they wrote it- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: I'm not sure that's something I want people to know about.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: You're not embarrassed, are you?

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: No, Robert, it's in the paper. What's the one thing we know about Zodiac? He reads the newspaper.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Oh, come on, it's not like- The PHONE RINGS. Graysmith rises and picks it up.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Mr. Graysmith? The Robert Graysmith mentioned in the paper today?

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Yes-—

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I can tell you who the Zodiac is.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Who is this-

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: The Zodiac Killer is so full of movies, he has records of his activities on film. I tried to tell the police but they wouldn't follow through on it. Are you ready for the important part, Mr. Graysmith?

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: There is a man you need to find. His name is Bob Vaughn, V-A-U... Graysmith snaps to Melanie for a pen. Writing on his hand

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: -..G-H-N. He is a friend of the Zodiac's. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Mr. Vaughn does not know his friend is a killer, and is storing some film canisters for him. In these canisters is the evidence you'll need.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: What's his name?

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You have quite enough to get started-

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Please. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: The Zodiac's name is Rick Marshall. CLICK. The man has hung up.

dialogues.speaker: MORRILL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Handwriting is everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Graysmith walks with Morrill through his GARDEN. Every so often, the handwriting expert stops to check a flower.

dialogues.speaker: MORRILL
dialogues.text: Can a fingerprint give you the key to a criminal's mental state? Can a shell casing give you insight to motive?

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: No?

dialogues.speaker: MORRILL
dialogues.text: Zodiac uses a mixture of cursive and printing. Most of us do. We choose at some point in our lives, how to physically construct each letter. Once we lock this into our brains, our handwriting may change over the years, but the moves themselves will remain unaltered. Do you understand?

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Yes. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MORRILL
dialogues.text: Except Zodiac's doesn't Specifically with his "k". In his

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: first letters, k's were executed with two strokes. Later letters, he did them with three.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: MORRILL
dialogues.text: We don't know. (re: the lilacs) I gotta spray these. Graysmith follows Morrill to his garage to get the spraye Morrill walks

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: How many suspects were cleared through handwriting?

dialogues.speaker: MORRILL
dialogues.text: All of them. Also, the print in the cab. No match was ever found.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Is there any way someone could beat a handwriting test?

dialogues.speaker: MORRILL
dialogues.text: No. Whoever the Zodiac is, he's not someone I cleared. back to the lilacs. Graysmith follows.

dialogues.speaker: MORRILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: About a month ago, a man named Wallace Penny showed up on my doorstep, very distraught. He said he knew who the Zodiac was. He gave me a name. Rick something- Graysmith stops in his tracks.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Marshall.

dialogues.speaker: MORRILL
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Rick Marshall. The same man you talked to called me... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 201 202 203 FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 154.

dialogues.speaker: MORRILL
dialogues.text: After he left, I went back through my files to check the name. I never cleared a "Rick Marshall" for handwriting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toschi sits with his new partner, eating lunch.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: You have any Animal Crackers? His partner looks at him like he's high.

dialogues.speaker: POLICE RADIO, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Twenty-two call in IMMEDIATELY. Land line only. Toschi looks over to see a POLICE CALL BOX on the corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Captain Lee picks up. Next to him, an excited DUFFY JENNINGS. INTERCUT with Toschi at the CALL BOX:

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: It's me, what's up?

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN LEE
dialogues.text: I've got Jennings from the Chron- Jennings snatches the phone out of his hand. Manic.

dialogues.speaker: JENNINGS
dialogues.text: Parker spotted it this morning, you gotta come in now and see it-

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: See what?

dialogues.speaker: JENNINGS
dialogues.text: A new Zodiac letter and it mentions you.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: (to his partner) We're gonna have to run some red lights.  204 205 FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 155.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toschi's car SCREAMS through the streets, SIREN BLARING..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toschi enters at a sprint, taking stairs two at a time. S Captain Lee at the top, flanked by TWO MEN in SUITS. Befo he reaches them:

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: You got it with you? Captain Lee hands it over. Toschi, reading aloud:

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Dear, Editor, This is the Zodiac speaking. I am back with you. Tell herb caen I am here, I have always been here. That city pig toschi is good, but I am smarter and better he will get tired then leave me alone. I am waiting for a good movie about me. Who will play me. I am now in control of all things. At the bottom of the page Yours Truly, O - guess

dialogues.speaker: S.F.P.D.
dialogues.text: Toschi stares at the letter and looks up again. Noticing men in suits for the first time. And Lee's expression. An the fact that the OTHER COPS PASSING them are EYEING HIM STRANGELY. Something's not right...

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN LEE
dialogues.text: Dave, these guys are from Internal Affairs. We need to talk.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN LEE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Dave, these guys are from Internal Affairs, they're gonna need a handwriting sample.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: What, you don't think I wrote this?  FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 155A.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Graysmith, sitting with his family, eating dinner. The television on in the other room. Faintly we hear the END THE NEWS INTRO THEME followed by: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: NEWSCASTER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Good evening. Our top story tonight, the San Francisco Police Department has confirmed that the man who called himself Zodiac and terrorized the Bay Area has broken his silence of fifty one months. In a letter claiming "I am back with you" the Zodiac makes no overt threats against the citizenry, and muses that his life and times would make the basis for a good movie. The terse sixty-six word missive also manages to mention both San Francisco Chronicle Columnist Herb Caen and the Department's own Inspector David Toschi by name. Are they targets? Or is something more at work here? Our team coverage on the Cipher Slayer's Return begins as Alan Freeman has more... DURING THIS - Graysmith looks up reflexively. Then sees Melanie staring at him. He tries to be good. The kids, watching this tennis match of looks. Takes a bite.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: These carrots are delicious-

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: Oh, just go. Graysmith bolts out of his chair and rushes into the livi room. The kids follow. ON TV:

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER
dialogues.text: ...-Thank you, Eric. These personal mentions have drawn controversial accusations from at least one source tonight as San Francisco Chronicle columnist Armistead Maupin has charged that not only is the new letter be a forgery, but that it was written by Toschi himself - the very man charged to hunt the Killer. Graysmith face pales. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER
dialogues.text: Maupin, a respected author best known for his "Tales of the City" stories, has gone on the record saying he believes Toschi wrote the letter to drum up publicity for himself. And the theory is gaining strength. Sources wishing to remain anonymous within the Hall of Justice say that Toschi has always had a weak spot where publicity was concerned...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TOSCHI'S WIFE, on the phone with Graysmith. Speaking in hushed tones so her husband doesn't overhear. INTERCUT:

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI'S WIFE
dialogues.text: Maupin used David as a character in his column. David got a kick out of it so he wrote a couple anonymous letters asking for the character to be brought back. It was like writing fan mail to himself, that's all. But David didn't write that letter.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: I know he didn't. I'm sure this will all blow over- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 207 208 FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 157.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI'S WIFE
dialogues.text: Blow over? She looks into the next room where Toschi sits. Staring o the window. DEVASTATED.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI'S WIFE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: They kicked him out of Homicide. They made him give his handwriting like some criminal-

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: May I talk to him?

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI'S WIFE
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Then could you ask if he ever investigated a man named Rick Marshall?

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI'S WIFE
dialogues.text: That is all you can think about?

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI'S WIFE
dialogues.text: Mr. Graysmith, Maupin works at your paper. We trusted you- Cut off as TOSCHI takes the phone from her and HANGS IT U Exchanges a look with his wife. Then he turns and goes ba to the living room, to sit with his drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Graysmith with Narlow.

dialogues.speaker: NARLOW
dialogues.text: Of course he doesn't want to talk, his career's over and your paper did it. I got half a mind to kick you out of here myself-

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Does the name Rick Marshall mean anything to you? This stops Narlow cold. He goes and shuts his office door Turns back to Graysmith, intrigued:

dialogues.speaker: NARLOW
dialogues.text: What are you after? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: What have you got?

dialogues.speaker: NARLOW
dialogues.text: Hypothetically? You just named my favorite suspect in the whole case. Couple years ago, I was trying to get his prints? Handed him a photo to look at. He takes it, is about to hand it back when he stops and says "My goodness, I got fingerprints all over this." Then he wipes them off.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Why wasn't he ever tested for handwriting?

dialogues.speaker: NARLOW
dialogues.text: Because they finally did get his prints and cleared him against the one in Stine's cab.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: (deflating) So it's not him.

dialogues.speaker: NARLOW
dialogues.text: Maybe yes, maybe no.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: NARLOW
dialogues.text: Zodiac left gloves behind. If you have the foresight to wear gloves while committing a murder, how the hell do you leave a fingerprint?

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: But it was in blood. They found it at the scene-

dialogues.speaker: NARLOW
dialogues.text: All it takes is one curious civilian or cop to reach out and touch something and boom - false print. Take a look at the crime scene photos, the cab wasn't that secure.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: That print was used to disqualify thousands of suspects. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: NARLOW
dialogues.text: Which is why we also used handwriting.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: But not with Marshall.

dialogues.speaker: NARLOW
dialogues.text: SFPD had a handwritten sign from the window of his house. Looked nothing like the Z letters so they moved on.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: What if he didn't write the sign?

dialogues.speaker: NARLOW
dialogues.text: My thoughts exactly. Marshall was a Navy man, received code training. He used to work as a projectionist at a silent film theater- Graysmith looks up.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: How much do you want to bet one of the films he projected was "The Most Dangerous Game"? Silence. Narlow stares at him.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How can I get a copy of Rick Marshall's handwriting?

dialogues.speaker: NARLOW
dialogues.text: Only three ways. One, get a warrant, which you can't - Two, get him to volunteer it which he won't-

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: And three?

dialogues.speaker: NARLOW
dialogues.text: Get creative.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Graysmith, on the phone with Morrill. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MORRILL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I don't know what to tell you. You get it, I'll analyze it. Beyond that, you're on your own. Graysmith runs his fingers through his hair.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: What about the man who came to see you? The one who called me-

dialogues.speaker: MORRILL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Wallace Penny.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Did he leave a number?

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: 209A Graysmith, dialing. The phone ringing. Then: 209A

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Hi, this is Robert Graysmith.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: How'd you find me?

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: I need a sample of Rick Marshall's handwriting.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I told you, Vaughn is the key-

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Mr. Penny, if Rick Marshall's the Zodiac, I need his handwriting to confirm it. Can you help or not? Silence. Then:

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Rick used to draw movie posters for the theater Vaughn worked at. I'll send one down.

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED 210
dialogues.text: 211 212 FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 161.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morrill stands over a table. Magnifying glass in hand, an heaping glass of scotch by his side. Examining the movie poster. Behind him, Graysmith waits, holding his breath.

dialogues.speaker: MORRILL
dialogues.text: I'll need more samples.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: But is it-

dialogues.speaker: MORRILL
dialogues.text: About as close as I've ever seen. And that's why I need more. We have to tread lightly here. We are talking about implicating this man as the Zodiac.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: I'll get more. I'1l find Vaughn. I'll track down Linda. It's weird, I've tried the DMV, Darlene's family - no one seems to know where she is-

dialogues.speaker: MORRILL
dialogues.text: Mr. Graysmith? Most of the writing matches the exemplar. In a way, though, it's the part that doesn't match that scares me the most.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: How do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: MORRILL
dialogues.text: The only letter on this poster that absolutely, positively does not match, is the letter "k".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Graysmith, brushing his teeth. Melanie, asleep. The PHONE RINGS. Graysmith runs to pick it up.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Hello? (no response) Hello? Who is this- He stops. Listening. Someone is on the other end. Just BREATHING... CLICK. The line goes dead. Graysmith hangs up. Turns to see MELANIE awake. Staring at him. Scared.  213 FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 162.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toschi, leaving for the day. He exits the front of the building with a couple of other cops, laughing and joking Heading down the sidewalk when he hears:

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Inspector! Dave! He turns to see Graysmith coming towards him. Looking a little more manic than usual. The other cops, sensing thi guy's a little off. Toschi turns to them:

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: I'll catch up with you. They go. Toschi turns to Graysmith.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You stop calling my house. That is unacceptable, do you understand?

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: (taken aback) I need your help to find Linda-

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: (turning away) Jesus...

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: We ran some handwriting samples-

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: We?

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: I'm working with Sherwood.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: Sherwood who got canned from Questioned Documents. Sherwood who drinks like Paul Avery now.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: He retired.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: Is that what he told you?

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Are you saying Sherwood's wrong? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: I'm saying stop calling my house. He turns to go. Graysmith, desperate to keep the conversation alive, follows him down the street.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: We ran them on Rick Marshall-

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: No, Robert.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: I know you don't think it's him-

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: I mean, no, I'm not having this conversation.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: I think Marshall knew Darlene. I can't find Mageau or Linda, but I'm gonna talk to Bob Vaughn- Toschi stops and turns to him. Amazed by the obsession.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: You need to get out of this.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: Robert, the Rick Marshalls of the world, the blind alleys will suck you dry.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: He said he wouldn't announce his murders anymore, he'd just do them!

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: You know what the chances of arresting someone are now? Too many years gone, too much evidence lost.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: But— (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: I've been a cop for twenty five years, murder police for ten. What do you for a living?

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: You know what I-

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: You're a cartoonist.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: So what are you saying?

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: Zodiac was my job. It's not yours. Graysmith, hurt. Toschi, satisfied he's gotten the messag He turns to leave when

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: He's still out there, Dave! Toschi turns back. Looking at him.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If you could just help me find Linda-

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: I'm done with this. And I am done with you. He turns on his heel and leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Graysmith gets out of his car to see Melanie hurrying dow the steps, harried. Before he can ask:

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: You were supposed to pick up the boys from soccer.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Oh, God, I'm sorry, it completely slipped my mind-

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: They're at the Coes. They tried to call you at work. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: I was with Dave-

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: So I had to leave my work, come home, I'm going to get them right now.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: I'll go-

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: I'm already here, Robert. I'm going. (getting in the car) You have to stop ignoring them.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: I don't ignore them- (off her look) I'm sorry. I'1l spend more time with the kids. I promise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 2 year old Margot sits in a highchair. Graysmith makes he sandwich. DAVID and AARON sit at the table, cross referencing dates from BOOKS, Aaron on the MISSING/MURDER LIST and David has the ASTROLOGICAL CHARTS.

dialogues.speaker: AARON
dialogues.text: What about September 26, 1970?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I'm checking... What is it?

dialogues.speaker: AARON
dialogues.text: Lake Tahoe nurse goes missing. David finds the date on the chart.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Uhhh, one day before the Vernal Equinox. Dad?

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Mark it. David turns to a LARGE BOARD and marks the nurse's name, of disappearance, and celestial significance.

dialogues.speaker: AARON
dialogues.text: Got another on June 19, 1971... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: All right - that's gotta be close to Summer Solstice. David flips through charts to check. He nods. Graysmith delivers Margot her sandwich.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: You boys might not want to mention our "special project" to your mother.

dialogues.speaker: AARON
dialogues.text: How come you guys don't sleep in the same bed now? This stops Graysmith cold. David gives his younger brothe dead arm. Before anyone can speak, the PHONE RINGS. Grateful for the distraction, Graysmith picks up.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: NARLOW
dialogues.text: Mr. Graysmith, it's Ken Narlow. You called?

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: We've been cross-referencing lunar cycles with the Zodiac's timeline - more often than not each cycle since '69 corresponds with a letter, an attack, or get this - an unsolved homicide.

dialogues.speaker: NARLOW, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Who do you have working with you? Graysmith glances at his sons.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Some colleagues.

dialogues.speaker: AARON
dialogues.text: Dad?

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Hang on a moment. (to Aaron) Yeah, buddy?

dialogues.speaker: AARON
dialogues.text: What's this? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: And he holds up the UNSOLVED 1969 CODE. at it and we... 166A. Graysmith, staring

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: 215  FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 167. 215A ON VIDEO: Graysmith sits awkwardly with an interview August 9, 1979. A NEWSCASTER OVER THIS:

dialogues.speaker: NEWSCASTER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: In the decade since the Zodiac's second cipher was received, every federal agency has taken a crack at decoding it. But today, we are pleased to announce that where those agencies had failed, a cartoonist has succeeded. Graysmith, cowed. The interviewer turns to him.

dialogues.speaker: INTERVIEWER
dialogues.text: How'd you do it?

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Ummm... A lot of books from the library... PULLING BACK from the TV until we realize we're in

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PAUL AVERY sits on a stool watching the report. OXYGEN TA perched on the stool next to him. Smoking. A BLUE GIRLY DRINK in front of him. Cackling:

dialogues.speaker: AVERY
dialogues.text: The fucking library...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Graysmith, on the phone. His hand, taking something down. It reads Linda - San Joaquin County Honor Camp.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: (into phone) Thank you, so much! He hangs up the phone and turns to see Melanie, ecstatic.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I found Linda! You know why it's taken me so long? Because she's in prison! Isn't that great?

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: Why'd you do it? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He looks at her, confused.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Because she's the key! If she can identify Marshall-

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: I'm not talking about Linda whoever. You went on TV. You put your face out there for him to see... Graysmith's face falls.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: You're being paranoid-

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: Who's been calling our house? At least once a week and you never let me answer.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: It's nobody.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: Right. A beat. Staring at her. She stares back.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What's it going to take for you to be done with this, Robert?

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: I don't have time to talk about this now, I have to meet Bob Vaughn-

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: Well, that's too bad, because we're talking about it. When's it going to be enough? When you catch him? When you arrest him?

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Be serious-

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: I am. Silence. Graysmith, slowly: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 217 218 FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 169.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: I need to know who he is. (pause) I need to stand there and look him in the eye and know it's him.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: And that's more important than your family's safety.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: I have to do this, Melanie.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: Why? (no response) Look at me, Robert. Why?

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Because nobody else will. She stares at him.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: That's not good enough for me.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: I have to go, are you done? She blinks. Stunned. Turns and walks out of the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The same address as in the phone book. Graysmith stands o the corner as a car pulls up. Very dark inside. All we se is a LIT CIGARETTE.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Robert Graysmith? Graysmith squints, he can't make out the man's features v well through the rain and darkness.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Mr. Vaughn?

dialogues.speaker: VAUGHN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You said you needed to talk to me?

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Yes. There's a coffee shop on the corner- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 218 219 FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 170.

dialogues.speaker: VAUGHN
dialogues.text: Why don't you just come to my house? The light of the cigarette exposes Vaughn's yellow smile.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: I wouldn't want to put you out-

dialogues.speaker: VAUGHN
dialogues.text: It's not far. (tosses the smoke) You can follow me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Graysmith follows the wild white haired Vaughn through th door of his house and into a cluttered living room.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Thank you for having me over- CLICK. Vaughn LOCKS THE DOOR from the inside WITH A KEY.

dialogues.speaker: VAUGHN
dialogues.text: Not at all. Vaughn takes a seat in an easy chair. Graysmith clears so magazines off the couch and sits across from him.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: I wanted to ask you about a particular film the Avenue may have run when you were an organist there. "The Most Dangerous Game".

dialogues.speaker: VAUGHN
dialogues.text: Classic. RKO, 1932. Fay Wray. We've run it many times.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: How about in 1969?

dialogues.speaker: VAUGHN
dialogues.text: I'd have to check my records. Why?

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: You remember the Zodiac Killer? Vaughn's face darkens. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: VAUGHN
dialogues.text: This is about Rick Marshall, isn't it? 170A. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 219  FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 71.
