dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: He worked as your projectionist?

dialogues.speaker: VAUGHN
dialogues.text: For a time. I don't have any occasion to correspond with him these days.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: There's a connection between one of the Zodiac attacks and the film-

dialogues.speaker: VAUGHN
dialogues.text: You mean the symbol. Graysmith doesn't follow. Vaughn pulls out a coil of FILM LEADER.

dialogues.speaker: VAUGHN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The Zodiac symbol on film. On the countdown. It's trimmed off each reel before they're shown, but it always arrives with it. First time I saw it in the papers, I immediately thought of this. Graysmith looks - STANDARD ACADEMY LEADER COUNTDOWN, whic looks EXACTLY LIKE A ZODIAC SIGN.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: We got a tip that Rick left a film canister with you. Something he told you never to open.

dialogues.speaker: VAUGHN
dialogues.text: A "tip" about a "mysterious film canister"?

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Is it true? Vaughn stares at him. Finally:

dialogues.speaker: VAUGHN
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Have you opened it?

dialogues.speaker: VAUGHN
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: May I see it? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 219 FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 172.

dialogues.speaker: VAUGHN
dialogues.text: Rick took it back in 1972. Graysmith's face falls.

dialogues.speaker: VAUGHN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And this "tip" is how you got it in your head that Rick's the Zodiac?

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: That and the movie posters.

dialogues.speaker: VAUGHN
dialogues.text: Excuse me? Graysmith fumbles out the folded poster.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: The handwriting on the posters Rick did. It's the closest we've ever come to a match-

dialogues.speaker: VAUGHN
dialogues.text: Rick didn't draw any posters.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: What? No, he did this one-

dialogues.speaker: VAUGHN
dialogues.text: Mr. Graysmith, I do the posters personally. That's my handwriting. An awful moment. Graysmith looks to the locked door. Vaug stares at him. Hard. Graysmith puts on a brave face. Rises.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: I won't take any more of your time-

dialogues.speaker: VAUGHN
dialogues.text: Not at all. Before you go, I should check on when we played that film.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: I don't want to trouble you-

dialogues.speaker: VAUGHN
dialogues.text: No trouble. The records are just down in the basement. A beat. Graysmith, echoing Toschi: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 219 220 FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 173.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Not many people have basements in California.

dialogues.speaker: VAUGHN
dialogues.text: (smiling) I do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door CREAKS OPEN. Vaughn and Graysmith stand at the t of a rickety wooden staircase. We hear WATER DRIPPING somewhere down in the darkness. Vaughn flicks a switch, a naked bulb snaps on somewhere below. Very little light. Graysmith really doesn't want to be here. Vaughn leads hi down the stairs, hand on his back as they walk.

dialogues.speaker: VAUGHN
dialogues.text: The very detailed posters I kept, but the one-off cheapos like that one there I just threw into the back alley... Here we go. They finally stop by an overstuffed bookshelf. Vaughn pul one handbound volume from it and begins flipping through pages. Graysmith looks around, nervous. The bulb above them flickers. Vaughn reaches up and tweak it with a finger - the light goes constant again. Above Graysmith's head, the CEILING BOARDS CREAK. As though someone were WALKING AROUND UPSTAIRS.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: You live alone? Vaughn nods absently, still searching the book.

dialogues.speaker: VAUGHN
dialogues.text: Here it is. "The Most Dangerous Game" - ran it May 1969. That would have been about nine weeks before the first Zodiac letter, correct? Graysmith, still looking up at the ceiling.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Yeah...

dialogues.speaker: VAUGHN
dialogues.text: You believe he saw the film at our theater and was inspired? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 220 221 222 223 FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 174.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: More FOOTSTEP CREAKS from above.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: You're sure no one else is in the house?

dialogues.speaker: VAUGHN
dialogues.text: Would you like to go and check?

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: That's all right. Thanks for everything. Graysmith turns and heads for the stairs. Forcing himself walk, not run. He climbs them, getting into...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Graysmith emerges from the cellar. Looking around. No one He hurries to the door, grasps the knob and... LOCKED. Fr the inside. Graysmith looks for the bolt. No way to unloc it. He's TRAPPED. The floorboards creak behind him and he SPINS TO SEE... VAUGHN. Standing in the cellar doorway. Slowly walking towards him. Menacing. Reaching into his pocket... and pulling out the KEY. He steps past Graysmit and unlocks the door for him.

dialogues.speaker: VAUGHN
dialogues.text: Have a good night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Graysmith exits his car, guzzling coffee, hair crazed. Ju back from his meeting with Vaughn, mumbling:

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Maybe there are two of them. Marshall did the killing, Vaughn wrote the letters...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Graysmith steps inside and takes two steps before realizi The HOUSE IS SILENT.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Hello? Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pokes his head into the room. Beds made. Not slept in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The same. He stands there. Goes back downstairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sits on the couch. His wife and children. GONE. Holdin a note: "Took the kids to Mom's. Don't call." He looks at the phone. Next to it a note in his own writi One he took down before. "Linda - San Joaquin County Honor Camp." He stares at the two notes. Two paths. But he already kno the one he's taken. He picks up the Linda note...

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED 225
dialogues.text: INT. SAN JOAQUIN HONOR CAMP —- LAUNDRY ROOM - AFTERNOON 2 Graysmith stands as a GUARD walks LINDA DEL BUONO up to h

dialogues.speaker: PRISON GUARD
dialogues.text: You got five minutes. INT. SAN JOAQUIN HONOR CAMP —- MEETING ROOM - DAY 225B The Guard departs to a safe distance. Linda taking in Graysmith. He looks terrible. Linda, wary.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: What's this about?

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Zodiac.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: (lighting a smoke) Figures. You got the look.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: What look?

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: Like you got it bad for this. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: I'm fine.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Tell me about this "painting party".

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: Told the cops about it forever ago. Darlene always had lots of boys around, even though she was married. This one guy was weird, though. He used to bring her presents from Mexico. I don't know why she was friends with him. She once told me he'd killed somebody.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: Yup. Maybe when he was in the service.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: The Navy?

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: I think so.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Was he into movies?

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: He wasn't into people, I can tell you that. This party Darlene threw, people were supposed to show up, have beers, help paint. This dude shows up in a suit. He sat alone in a chair, didn't talk to anyone. Creeped me out. Darlene told me not to go near him. She was scared of him. Couple weeks later, she was dead. She takes a long shaky drag on her cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Do you remember his name? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: It was short. Like a nickname. Rob or Stan or-

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Rick? Or Bob maybe? She looks at him strangely. A long beat. Then:

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: No. No, I don't think so.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Rick or Bob - are you sure?

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: How can you be sure? Think hard-

dialogues.speaker: LINDA, (GETTING ANNOYED)
dialogues.text: I am thinking hard- He grasps her arm. The Guard starts moving towards them..

dialogues.speaker: PRISON GUARD
dialogues.text: Hey!

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Rick Marshall or Bob Vaughn, it was one of those names, wasn't it-

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: No-

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Yes-—

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: Christ, mister, it wasn't Rick or Bob! The Guard separates them. He stumbles back. Stands there. Wife gone. Life ruined.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. I'll go. He turns and walks away. She watches him go. Broken. Done She blinks as it comes to her:

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: It was Lee. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: 225B CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Graysmith STOPS IN HIS TRACKS.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Leigh? He turns back to her.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: Yeah, Leigh. That sounds right...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rain, now POURING. Graysmith, standing outside of the department. Mulanax blocking his entry. Both men, shoutin at each other over the weather:

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: I just need to see one file-

dialogues.speaker: MULANAX
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, I talked to Dave Toschi. He said I shouldn't-

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: I remember a name! I saw a name!

dialogues.speaker: MULANAX
dialogues.text: Mr. Graysmith, you need to go home-

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: One file! Please! I've got the name!

dialogues.speaker: MULANAX
dialogues.text: (turning away) I'm sorry...

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Please! This is all I've got! Mulanax stops. Turning back to him. Graysmith, soaked. At the end of his rope. Begging.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Please... Mulanax steps aside and lets him in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Graysmith puts a piece of paper down on Mulanax's desk. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Here! "Linda states that some of Darlene's closest friends are LEE who used to bring Darlene presents from Tia Juana"-

dialogues.speaker: MULANAX
dialogues.text: So what?

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: He knew her! Linda said Leigh! This is Leigh!

dialogues.speaker: MULANAX
dialogues.text: No, that's one name in a file that contains hundreds. It's nothing.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: But you said Dave Toschi-

dialogues.speaker: MULANAX
dialogues.text: Agrees with me. Our investigation into this suspect is over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rain pounds the roof. The contents of his ZODIAC INVESTIGATION now COVER THE EMPTY LIVING ROOM. Tacked up every wall, papers all over the floor. Furniture pushed aside. It's overwhelming. Graysmith, on the floor, scrapi through pages. Hasn't eaten or slept for days. MUMBLING t himself.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: You made a mistake somewhere, where were you weak, where did you make a mistake... The phone rings. Graysmith picks up.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hello? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 232 FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 180.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The BREATHING again. Slow and steady as ever. He SLAMS th phone down. Goes back to a file. Accidentally knocking ov his coffee, dumping it all over the pages.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Goddammit ! Graysmith HEAVES the java soaked file across the room. It lands on the floor next to a pair of FEMALE FEET. Pan up reveal MELANIE, standing in the open doorway.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: You didn't return my calls. Graysmith, stunned to see her.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: I've been kind of busy.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: (looking around) I can see. The book's going well? He doesn't respond. They stare at each other. Two people who no longer know how to act around one another.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I called the Chron...

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: I'm not a cartoonist anymore.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: I heard. When's the last time you ate something?

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Can I have that file back? She walks over and hands it to him.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He made a mistake, he made a mistake... It takes him a second to realize he's speaking aloud. Looking up at her. Like a child.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Nothing makes sense anymore... She looks around the room at the mountain of papers. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 232 233 FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 181.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: Did it ever?

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Yeah. It did. It's clear he's talking about her.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: Robert. It was just the date that never ended.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Do you think-

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: No. He just stares at her, numb. Then nods.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But we have a daughter together. You have two good sons. They miss you.

dialogues.speaker: I...
dialogues.text: (looking around) I don't want them to see me like this...

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: Neither do I. But I will not let you lose them. Do whatever you have to. But finish this. Silence. Melanie turns and walks out. Graysmith sits. Alone. Looking at the MOUNTAINS OF PAPERS. Years of his life, gone. He slowly starts collecting them. Cleaning up Wiping the coffee stained papers off. One, a DMV SHEET on ARTHUR LEIGH ALLEN. And there it is, right at the top. Graysmith stops. STARING at it. And we pull away from him as he stands stock-still rooted to the ground...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rain has mellowed into a light shower. A TAPPING on t window. Faintly:

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (whispering) Dave! Dave! He made a mistake! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Toschi blinks awake. Next to him, his wife does the same.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI'S WIFE
dialogues.text: Is he actually here? Toschi sits up. Graysmith seeing him, thrilled:

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: He made a mistake! I'1l meet you around front!

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: Robert, don't- But Graysmith's already going from the window, excited. Toschi, pulling on his robe...

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Call SFPD, I'm gonna shoot him...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toschi walking down the hall. Graysmith, now lightly knocking on the door.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: Go away, Robert!

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You need to hear this-

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: No I don't!

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: The birthday! The one time he was weak, the one time he gave something away!

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: I'm calling the cops-

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: (screaming) It's Arthur Leigh Allen! A pregnant moment. Graysmith stares at the door. Then - tumblers in the lock. The DOOR SWINGS OPEN revealing (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: Where did you get that name? Graysmith, surprised to be granted an audience. Still

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: The call to Belli's house December '69, "I have to kill, today's my birthday"? It was his birthday! Arthur Leigh Allen was born on December 18th! He slaps the wet DMV sheet up against the door. DOB 12/18/33. Toschi stares at it. A beat and then...

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: Get in here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toschi hands Graysmith a MUG of steaming coffee, then tak seat across from him at the kitchen table.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: He wrote me, you know. (pause) 2500 different suspects. And the only one who ever wrote me a letter is Leigh Allen.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Sometimes killers want to help out-

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: Robert, I know this. (pause) He was arrested for molestation in January '75. Sent me this when he got out. He slides a LETTER across the table.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: “Sorry, I wasn't your man. If I can help out"- This is typewritten.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: Using a typewriter isn't a crime.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: He knew her, Dave. This was in the Vallejo files. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: 233F
dialogues.text: He shows Toschi Linda's statement.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Mulanax said he was your favorite suspect. That you spent two years on him. That nobody else came close-

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: The evidence all said no. Sherwood disqualified him.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: The same Sherwood who drinks like Paul Avery now?

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: What are you telling me?

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Sherwood's wrong. Toschi looks down at the Date of Birth. Then back up to Graysmith.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: I'll show you mine, you show me yours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A misty morning. On a tiny coffee shack below the bridge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Graysmith and Toschi, in a booth. Empty breakfast plates pushed aside, SURROUNDED by both the SFPD and GRAYSMITH'S ZODIAC FILES. At this all night. Graysmith, gesturing to SFPD handwriting reports.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: +..-you have Sherwood in writing saying "I'm sorry this just won't work", and Terry Pascoe-

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: His protege-

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Fine, his protege, but a handwriting expert saying "Do not disqualify this suspect on the basis of handwriting". These two cancel each other out- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: No, because it was Sherwood's case. He was the head of Questioned Documents. If it went to trial, all the defense would have to do is call Sherwood to the stand - and there was no way to get Allen into court in the first place because there was no evidence.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: But you have him seen with ciphers, the military bootprints, the same size shoes and gloves, "The Most Dangerous Game", the Zodiac watch-

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: Robert-

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: -the background with school kids, the misspellings of "Christmas", the bloody knives in the car, the connections to the murder scenes-

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: It's all circumstantial. Stine's shirt, his wallet, his keys - we should have found one of those things in that trailer. We didn't. He sighs, running his hand through his hair. Graysmith an he begins digging through the folders.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Hang on a second.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: The trailer, I saw- (finding it) Here. From Catherine Allen - "Leigh cleaned out his trailer Friday after work and took it to Santa Rosa Saturday August 7,

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: Yeah? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: 233F CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Toschi stares

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: You interviewed him at the refinery Wednesday August 4th. (pause) He's cleaning out his trailer and moving it to a different county 48 hours after you interviewed him. at him.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You have to look at this stuff side by side.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Allen and the Zodiac. Their timelines. When was the first murder in Vallejo?

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: Christmas of 68.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Eight months after Allen's fired for molesting children and his family discovers he was a pedophile. When did the letters begin?

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: July of 69.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: After the second murder and they continue until you interview Allen. Did any letters after that contain swatches of Stine's shirt?

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Because he dumped it. He got scared. Because you went to see him at work. When's the next time Zodiac wrote?

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: Not until January of 1974. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Which means he's silent for three years after you talk to him. But by '74 he feels safe again. Everyone's moved off Allen as a suspect. So Zodiac writes three new letters - January, May, and July in '74.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: But then the letters stopped again.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: What happened to Allen?

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: He was arrested. January of '75. They sent him to Atascadero. We didn't get a single letter while he was in there.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: And when is he released?

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: August of '77.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: He gets out, writes you, and then? We get our first new Zodiac letter in four years. (pause) What do you think? Toschi leans forward.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: I've got one question. Graysmith looks at him, expectantly.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Zodiac had to have known Darlene Ferrin, right?

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Because of the phone calls on the night of her murder, that's right.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: And because of this report, we know Darlene knew a man named "Lee". (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: All coincidence aside, how can you be sure that Leigh Allen is the "Lee" in the report? Vallejo's a small town but it's not that small. How do you know they're connected? Silence. Graysmith stares at him.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: This is a case that's covered both Northern and Southern California with suspects and victims spread out across hundreds of miles, would you agree?

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Allen lived in his mother's basement on Fresno Street. Darlene worked as a waitress at the Vallejo House of Pancakes. (pause) Leigh Allen lived less than fifty yards away. A long beat.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: Christ.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Do you think it's him?

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: The prints and handwriting-

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: I'm not asking the cop, I'm asking my friend - do you think it's him?

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: Yes. (pause) But we could never prove it. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Just because you can't prove something doesn't mean it's not true. Toschi looks at him. Nods.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: I gotta get going. I start in burglary today. (pause) Let me buy you breakfast. Toschi puts some money on the table. Rises. Heads for the door...

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Dave? When did you know? Toschi turns back.

dialogues.speaker: TOSCHI
dialogues.text: The minute I laid eyes on him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just opening for business. A car pulls into the lot. Graysmith.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Graysmith enters the store. Looking for someone. A HEAVY BALD CLERK, stocking. We see him only from behind...

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Excuse me? The clerk turns and flashes a smile. His nameplate reads "LEE". He wears a ZODIAC WATCH on his wrist. They stand three feet apart. Graysmith stares at him. Looking him in the eye... Allen's smile fades. Realizing why Graysmith's there. He frowns. His face transforms. An we see how terrifying this man really could be. They hold each other's gaze for what seems like forever... And Allen finally looks away. Graysmith blinks. Once. Getting what he came here for. Knowing for sure. Graysmit turns and walks out of the store.

dialogues.speaker: 235A OMITTED 235A
dialogues.text: 236 FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 190.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: July 4th, 1989 - Vallejo, California. AN AMERICAN FLAG fluttering in the breeze. Twilight. The sun, giving way t a crisp summer evening. The PARKING LOT where Darlene Fer died. Twenty years later. Graysmith sits on the hood of h car, sipping a Diet Coke. Older and grayer.

dialogues.speaker: BAWART, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Twenty years, huh? Darlene and Mike - right there. Graysmith looks up to see GEORGE BAWART ambling towards h Pointing at the spot the Corvair parked.

dialogues.speaker: BAWART, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Kind of amazing, a guy shoots a couple of farm kids, writes some letters, and we're still talking about it. Robert Graysmith, I presume.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Sergeant Bawart?

dialogues.speaker: BAWART
dialogues.text: Call me George. I took over for Jack Mulanax a couple years back.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: How'd you know it was me? Bawart holds up a copy of the book.

dialogues.speaker: BAWART
dialogues.text: Your cover photo. (looking around) So Mike Mageau never made a positive ID on anyone, huh?

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: I could never find him.

dialogues.speaker: BAWART
dialogues.text: You talk to his family? Graysmith looks at him. Defensive.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Why'd you ask me here, Sergeant? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: On Graysmith. FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 191. 236

dialogues.speaker: BAWART
dialogues.text: Wanted to tell you something. Couldn't do it over the phone. (pause) We've reopened the case on Arthur Leigh Allen. His vindication.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: BAWART
dialogues.text: Really. (pause) We don't want that getting around-

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: I understand-

dialogues.speaker: BAWART
dialogues.text: It's your book that did it. A beat as this sinks in.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: (flustered) I never meant for it- I mean, I got some of it wrong-

dialogues.speaker: BAWART
dialogues.text: You got a lot of it right, too. (chuckling; to the book) I don't know how a civilian found out half this stuff - hell, as a cop I probably don't want to know, but things are moving again. We found Robert Emmet the hippie. (off Graysmith's look) Yup, Robert Emmet Rodifer, went to high school with Leigh, he's over in Germany. We're also onto a guy named Spinelli - claims Allen told him he was gonna go to San Francisco and shoot a cabbie.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Seriously?

dialogues.speaker: BAWART
dialogues.text: Seriously. There's one more thing. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He takes a step closer to Graysmith. Confidentially:

dialogues.speaker: BAWART, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Allen's sick. He's got diabetes, maybe terminal. So even if we get him - he's already got. You understand?

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: But you have to do it anyway, right?

dialogues.speaker: BAWART
dialogues.text: Hell, no one else will. Any case, I thought you deserved to know.

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: I appreciate it. Good luck. He offers a hand and Bawart shakes it.

dialogues.speaker: BAWART
dialogues.text: Hey, you wanna go grab a bite, talk the case a bit? Tempting - the old Graysmith would have said yes ina heartbeat. But he smiles as he realizes his answer is

dialogues.speaker: GRAYSMITH
dialogues.text: Not really. But thanks.

dialogues.speaker: BAWART
dialogues.text: Mr. Graysmith, thank you. Graysmith smiles. Gets into his car. Bawart watches as he drives away.  237 238 239 240 241

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHOOM! A PLANE coming in for a landing...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: August 16, 1991. Bawart comes down an escalator. Clutchin a briefcase. Passing an in-terminal BARNES AND NOBLE. Paperbacks of Robert Graysmith's "Zodiac" on display. Bawart strides up to a SECURITY GUARD. They're expecting him. He's led to a PRIVATE ROOM at the back of the airport...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bawart alone. Opening the briefcase. Extracting several files, a well dog-eared copy of Graysmith's book, a MANIL ENVELOPE, and a HOGAN HIGH YEARBOOK...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MIKE MAGEAU being led by security to the private room. Bedraggled hair, skittish face. Life has not been kind...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door opens and Bawart looks up from a YEARBOOK PHOTO Young Mike Mageau, to see the real version standing in fr of him. He rises, extending a hand.

dialogues.speaker: BAWART
dialogues.text: Mr. Mageau, thank you for seeing me.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: You're the one I talked to on the phone?

dialogues.speaker: BAWART
dialogues.text: Yes, sir, George Bawart, Vallejo PD, I took over the case from Jack Mulanax.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: It's been twenty two years, I don't know how I can help you... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 237 238 239 240 241  241 FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 192A.

dialogues.speaker: BAWART
dialogues.text: This is just a formality. I'm going to show you a group of photographs. The person that shot you may or may not be among this group of photographs. You don't have to pick anybody out just because I'm showing you these pictures. Do you understand?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Yes, sir, I do. Bawart picks up the envelope and extracts a PHOTO ARRAY f it. LEIGH ALLEN'S FACE among five others. He places the photo array down on the table. Mike frowns, staring down at the different pictures...

dialogues.speaker: BAWART
dialogues.text: Take your time. If you don't recognize anyone that's okay. Mike stares at the pictures for 15 seconds. Then: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 241 242 FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 193.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: That's him. Mike stabs his finger down at a picture. A YOUNG ARTHUR LEIGH ALLEN. Bawart blinks.

dialogues.speaker: BAWART
dialogues.text: How sure are you?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Pretty sure. He had a round face like this guy. He points to the picture of a SECOND MAN.

dialogues.speaker: BAWART
dialogues.text: Are you identifying this second person as well?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: No, no, just that he has a round face like that. It's this man. He taps the photo of Allen.

dialogues.speaker: BAWART
dialogues.text: On a scale of one to ten, how sure are you?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: It's at least an eight. Only other time I saw this face was on July 4, 1969. I'm very sure that's the man who shot me.

dialogues.speaker: A BLACK SCREEN. 242
dialogues.text: Silence. The following words appear: In 1991 Arthur Leigh Allen's basement was searched by the Vallejo Police Department. In it were found bomb diagrams explosive devices, 7 handguns, 4 rifles, and codebooks. In order to secure the warrant, Don Cheney, the man who f implicated Allen as the Zodiac, was given a polygraph tes He passed with flying colors. These words fade. Replaced by: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 242 FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 194.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Following Mike Mageau's identification of Allen as the Zo Police were scheduled to meet on August 27, 1992 to discu arresting him for the murders. Allen suffered a fatal heart attack one day before this meeting took place. No arrest was ever made. These words fade. Replaced by: Inspector David Toschi retired from the San Francisco Pol Department in 1989. He was completely cleared of all char that he wrote the 1978 Zodiac letter. Politically destroyed by the allegation, however, he neve rose above the rank of Inspector. These words fade. Replaced by: In 2001 DNA tests were run on several of the Zodiac envelopes. The San Francisco lab claimed DNA found under stamps did not match Arthur Leigh Allen's. Some believe these tests exonerated Arthur Leigh Allen. Others believe Zodiac would not have licked his own stamp since saliva typing tests were already common in 1969. In 2004, the San Francisco Police Department officially deactivated the Zodiac investigation. The Zodiac cases in Vallejo, Napa, and Solano County remain open to this day. These words fade. Replaced by: Today Robert Graysmith lives in San Francisco and enjoys healthy relationship with his children. Many people belie he was wrong in his conclusions on the Zodiac case. The anonymous phone calls he was receiving abruptly cease 1992. Not a single one has occurred since Allen's death.
